150973654.review:
Is this overly moe to be overly moe? Yes. Is it overly fanservice-y? Yeah, more than I'd like. Would you want to play this with your loved ones in the house? Only if your loved one is a spouse who really loves these kinds of things too. Does that stop me, a very acey person from playing the series as a whole? Not really.

But - Idea Factory and Compile Heart made the Neptunia mainline games with what I would argue is a great attention to detail. They're all commentary on the videogame industry as a whole - as if the world being called Gameindustri was not enough of a hint. Characters have names that are either overtly references, Arfoire the main antag being R4, a cart used for piracy and her Japanese name being a play on slang for piracy tech in the Japanese market as well, or sometimes a bit less direct like Rom and Ram, two demigod like beings that I still don't see the name puns for on anything but their starting gear which includes the Wi and Fi bangles. 
Every character has relevance either to the overall story as you'd expect or in the abstract sense of being referential to major companies. Broccoli for instance, the charming little cat person who keeps saying "Nyu" is a reference name and all to the Broccoli company in Japan, a media company that deals in manga, games, and anime. 
The layers -are- there for players who are willing to think critically and look past "haha cute moe girls and pngs with jiggle physics," and that honestly makes it cater to so many people it's kind of wild.

149397189.review:
This was my first Neptunia game, and I'll start by saying I mostly had a great time. Playing this reminded me of those good old days where you could have simple mechanics and a lighthearted / comedic story to push the narrative. Overall, it's a solid 9 / 10 in my book with some gripes. 

If you just want a solid RPG with cute characters then definitely play it. It's easy to learn, and can be extremely punishing if you forget to save often. There is no auto save, and a lack of ability to gauge monster levels. The game has a crap load of content and things to do, a lot to collect, and you are always making progress in some form or another. The DLC grows it even farther if you're starving for more content, while also raising the level cap to 999 and providing additional characters to play as. Graphics could be a little better, and enemies could be reused a little less, but those are not something I'd complain about. I bought all the other mainline entries, and am looking forward to playing them. 

It's impressive how large the cast of characters are, but it does cause the game to give less attention to the cast outside the leading group. It reminds me a bit of Persona 3 with the big variety of weapons, which are character locked. So you can't exactly swap them around. I do really like the way that depending on the version of a weapon you have, the hit box changes. I kind of wish it was executed better though. 

As with any other RPG, you will default to using the version with the highest stats. But that may mean you're stuck with the small square hit box, versus the wider rectangles with no real choice over it. I'd think it'd be more interesting if the Great-swords Neptune can use were all large hit boxes. And the Katana looking swords were small hit boxes with a critical chance boost or something to make them stand out. Then it'd be preference for which type you wanted. Or maybe it's fine just the way it is, giving you a taste of variety without really being in depth. This game's strongest positives are in it's simplicity after all.

I have a few minor complaints, that for the average person who plays a game once and drops it will likely mean nothing. But for those who like to do 100% completion as much as they can like myself, you are in for serious pain. The grind is soul breaking. I feel dead inside doing the same mindless dlc battle over and over and over trying to reach 100 million credits. Not to mention how many craft able items there are in the game (Most of which are useless by the time you get the rng drops to make them.) 

60 hours, multiple start to finish play throughs, And characters at level 200 with 11,881,301 / 100,000,000 credits. The worst offender has to be various upgrade chips and end game armor that relies on entering and exiting a dungeon upwards of 30 times to run to treasure spots. I'll only subtract the single point from this, as it really takes away from what was otherwise the most chill and enjoyable experience I've had in a long time. 

On a final note, if you check the guides section there is an amazing community mod to improve the game's shaders and resolution. Do check it out.

149030379.review:
I can't believe it's not kusoge!

The story of Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 isn't really anything special. It's ultimately just kind of a generic save-the-world adventure story and the actual substance is in the (comedic) character interactions more than anything else. I don't think I can claim to have loved the story, but I did find it charming in its own way. At least I don't regret reading through it. The English translation seems a bit liberal, but not to a degree that it'd completely ruin the entire thing either.

The combat is surprisingly good. There's kind of a good rhythm to the whole thing, where you first try to get a sneak attack in the overworld, then take turns in the battle to position yourself optimally, chip away at the enemy's shields and then deal heavy damage to them. During boss fights you would also look to optimise the mileage you get out of your powerful EX skills too. It's also fairly fast-paced, with the possibility to skip most of the animations, so you can really charge through your battles.

And boy is it a good thing the combat feels as good as it does since this game leans very heavily on grinding to pad out the game. I don't think there's any way to get through the story without grinding. You just won't get the levels to clear all the level check bosses. I had trouble beating a couple of the bosses, both early in the game and late in the game, and when I searched for tips in case I missed something, most of the advice on the Internet was "grind more". So if there's a way to beat the game without grinding, it went unnoticed by me and seemingly the rest of the Internet too.

The grinding also extends to the achievements. About half of the achievements for this game require grinding, be it for character levels or money. The amount of grinding is pretty mental. Really has this "low budget, must stretch out the game somehow" thing written all over it.

Not to say that there's no aspect for battle tactics and gameplay. For example, I lost to a boss, restarted the fight and then won the second bout. No grinding needed in the between the attempts. However, I'm not sure if the victory game down to skills or just luck. I feel like there's a limited amount of things you can do in regards to your tactics when the boss has the ability to insta-kill two members from your three-member party. It's quite possible that the boss just unleashed less of its wave of death area-of-effect attacks on my party on the latter attempt.

The rest of the game mechanics are kinda lame. The quests feel like they were added to check a checkbox, same as with the colosseum. And the share balancing act that you need to do in order to unlock the true ending or to unlock the little sisters is also not amazing, especially since it'll involve those quests and colosseum. Not massively time consuming thankfully, but still a bit of a mindless grind, doing the same things again and again to shift some percentages around.

Technically the game isn't the best. While I do like the art, despite the fact that the game reuses assets like it's going out of fashion, the graphics felt so bad and blurry at the beginning that I felt the need to install the Neptastic Mod on my Steam Deck. That did certainly help the game look nicer, although the FPS would not necessarily always be a stable 60 FPS. It also felt like the FPS would gradually get worse as I kept the game open as the Steam Deck was asleep. I think I went from around 40 FPS to 60 FPS in the same dungeon by just simply restarting the game. Deck users beware.

But in general, Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 does run pretty well on a Steam Deck. Maybe not as well as you'd expect considering that this is originally a PlayStation Vita game, but well enough even with the modding. Combined with the fast-paced combat and heavy focus on grinding, it makes for a pretty decent portable time killer when you have a couple of minutes to do something. Not really sure if I'd ever want to actually sit in front of my gaming PC and play through this game. It just doesn't feel like that kind of a game (quite possibly due to its Vita roots), which is why I played it from start to finish on the Steam Deck. Fairly certain even that I beat most of the game while sitting on the toilet.

Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 is a bit of a messy game with good core gameplay loop and enough charm to keep you around. For the couple of euro I paid for it, it did make for some good portable entertainment. Just don't really expect much beyond that from it.

147618612.review:
A pretty traditional JRPG where numbers matter a lot and strategy isn't especially important (not that there aren't any strategy elements, but it's not the biggest focus of the game).
Quite the lighthearted story, with some fanservice-y stuff along the way. Not a life-changing game, but not every game needs to be like that.
Lighthearted as it is, though, there are some complex mechanics outside of battle, like "Shares" between the console-parody realms, which increase or decrease based on the sidequests you take on during the game, or the "Crafting" system, which lets you create secret levels with rare drops (which is a fancy way to say you'll need to grind quite a lot).

It's your average turn-based anime RPG, and it doesn't need to be anything else. It's the beginning of the Neptunia series, but it can be enjoyed as a standalone product. It's really old now, but its price is just fine for the amount of hours you can get from it.

As an addendum, note that all achievements can be obtained without DLCs, but the Colosseum DLC is highly recommended just so you can easily farm cash for the money achievement.

147069347.review:
Disclaimer: I didn't finish this game, I stopped during like the third main-dungeon.
I purchased this game on a whim when it was on sale.
The combat system appeared to be similar-ish to the one in Yakuza 7, so I ended up giving this game a shot, despite it's poor reputation.
The game's intro-cutscene immediately jumpscared me with a lot of Loli-jiggle, which I am willing to accept to an extent, but it was too much for me personally lolz.
The combat-system appears to be a neat idea, but it somehow didn't feel like the game is balanced all that well.
The first 3 dungeons boiled down to "grind X amount of levels and beat a boss". I attempted to beat the first bosses with as low a level as I could, and it became kinda apparent that this game doesn't give you many tools to overcome a stronger opponent. Maybe things would improve during the mid-game, but judging by what I read in a lot of chats, it doesn't feel very likely. Once I reached a level on which the boss became beatable, they almost ceased to be a threat at all.
It almost feels like the balance is either strong in favour of the player, or strong in favour of the enemy, but I might be mistaken.
I kinda wanna finish the game just to give it a fair-chance, but I can't bring myself to do it.
I'm sorry lol.
Maybe you'll have more fun with this game than I had, and maybe I'll revisit it someday, but I don't think it's likely. I don't wanna insult the devs or the fans though, every game has it's virtues, however I appear to fail at appreciating Nep Nep's virtues.

146150506.review:
Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth 1 was an incredibly joyous experience for me. It really falls under the category of games that you have to try for yourself to see whether you like it or not, but in my case, I could not sing its praises enough.

Is it perfect? Haha, not particularly. If you held me at gunpoint, there's plenty of thing to nitpick about. Mechanics that could've been explained better, some odd mechanical interactions, and somewhat inconsistent DLC quality (from what I've heard around) do hold the game back a bit. But it never bothered me much.

Neptunia is a celebration of video games as an art form. It is a wonderful outlet brimming with endless amounts of memorable stories, characters, music, gameplay, and charm that stick with a person long after putting the controller down. The witty dialogue and countless references to gaming culture plastered a smile so profoundly stupid on my face, you'd need a pair of pliers to undo it. Getting to experience it alongside my wonderful friends no doubt played some part in that as well!

It really goes to show that if you have even the slightest passing interest in something...what are you waiting for? Our time on Earth is limited, and we're all ticking down each day of our lives. In this case, I think the ancient phrase bears worth repeating; the proof is in the pudding. And between you and me, I think you'll really like the pudding. <3

142161367.review:
To sum it up- Neptunia is a game about games; or more aptly a game that pokes fun at and often parodies the industry in an oddly endearing way. Its references are as on the nose as you can get and any ounce of subtlety is completely vacant in the world literally called "Gameindustri". If you've ever wanted to see video game consoles primarily of the 7th generation as cute anime girls you might just get something out of this.

A hamstrung dub helps with its tone too and I can't see myself playing any other way- only like half of the game is dubbed but the performances range from surprisingly compelling to hilariously bad with lots of recognisable dub voice actors considering there is like 5 in the industry pre 2020.

The game is self-referential constantly breaking the 4th wall in a way that doesn't feel tiresome like it usually does and an apt amount of self-mockery makes you laugh alongside the game rather than at it. Combined with a plethora of references to anime, games and pop culture the game is basically farming the Steve Rogers "I got that reference" GIF until you laugh, which if you're as easily impressed as I am will be as soon as the Steins;Gate references start happening.

The gameplay is errrrr the most serviceable JRPG of all time and has the most abysmal and draining grinding of any game I've played for a very long time although we could really reach and say this is the developers performing some crazy feat of ludo-narrative harmony at making fun of how bad JRPG grinding is- alas, even I'm not that deluded and infatuated with the game to begin to claim that.

It definitely did something right for me to bother going out of my way to buy its DLCs and 100% the game but I can confidently say that wasn't the gameplay. The story and characters aren't great but they're endearing and Neptune is like a silly little creature you just wanna watch on her ADHD-fuelled rampage.

Xbox 360/10- weirdest Sci;Adv VN ever.

140002952.review:
A Whimsical and Hilarious Adventure in Gamindustri!

Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 is a delightful and quirky RPG that combines a unique premise with lighthearted humor, charming characters, and a surprisingly deep gameplay experience. If you're a fan of anime-style RPGs with a healthy dose of self-awareness and references to gaming culture, this game is sure to entertain you.

The story takes place in the fictional world of Gamindustri, where four goddesses representing popular gaming consoles rule over different regions. The concept of personifying consoles as goddesses is not only creative but also provides ample opportunities for clever gaming references and parodies. The dialogue is filled with witty banter and fourth-wall-breaking humor, often poking fun at gaming tropes and industry stereotypes. While the plot itself may not be groundbreaking, the game's comedic tone and self-referential nature make it a joy to experience.

The characters in Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 are a major highlight. Each goddess has her distinct personality and quirks, and their interactions are amusing and endearing. From Neptune's carefree and energetic nature to Noire's tsundere tendencies, the characters are brought to life with vibrant voice acting and colorful visuals. The game also features a wide range of supporting characters, each with their own unique traits and storylines, adding depth and variety to the overall narrative.

In terms of gameplay, Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 offers a satisfying mix of turn-based combat and dungeon exploration. Battles are strategic, allowing for positioning and skill management, and the ability to chain attacks for devastating combos adds an extra layer of depth. The Lily Rank system, which strengthens bonds between characters, adds another tactical element to battles. While the combat mechanics may not be as complex as other RPGs, they are enjoyable and well-suited to the game's overall tone.

The visual presentation of Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 is colorful and charming, with vibrant character designs and detailed environments. The game's soundtrack is catchy and complements the on-screen action effectively, enhancing the overall immersion.

One potential downside is that the game's pacing can feel slow at times, with lengthy dialogue sequences and backtracking through previously visited areas. However, the humorous and light-hearted tone often makes up for this, keeping the player engaged and entertained.

It's worth mentioning that Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 is a remake of the original Hyperdimension Neptunia game, and it brings significant improvements and enhancements to the table. The updated graphics, additional story content, and improved gameplay mechanics make it the definitive version of the game.

Overall, Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 offers a fun and charming RPG experience with a unique concept and endearing characters. Its blend of humor, gaming references, and enjoyable gameplay makes it a solid choice for fans of the genre. If you're looking for a light-hearted and whimsical adventure that doesn't take itself too seriously, this game is well worth your time.

139373354.review:
TL,DR: I will recommend it only if you like absolute mindless game while doing something else, like listening to podcasts.

Rebirth 1 is like a slightly sweet cotton candy: sweet but not too sweet, fluffy and fun, but you forgot that you ate it 10 minutes later.

The gameplay is dated and grindy, especially if you want to unlock all characters and all items in the game, which requires multiple playthroughs. While it is a turn based combat, the enemy never intentionally combine their abilities to kill you. If they do, usually it's because they lucked in getting debuff stick to you or they just have big damage numbers. Most of the progression requires you to find and defeat the same enemies that you can kill with one strike over and over again, just to get a material for an upgrade.

The sheer amount of asset reuse is horrendous (music, environment, enemies), but not a deal breaker for me. You got wolves with red color, with blue color, and then slightly bigger wolves. Then the same dungeons with exact same layout, but the entrance is in a different place. If each area has unique mechanics or if the enemy has unique characteristics, I wouldn't mind. But they don't.

Neptunia is known to have lighthearted story, but the tone is weirdly inconsistent. Sometimes the game wants to go serious, but then undercut itself with 4th wall breaking jokes or quips. And no character got any character development. They are flat piece of 2D cardboard, and every conversation is just to move the plot along. If the character interacts, it's usually just for a joke. You'll never have characters talk about their own problems.

Which brings me to the last bastion of hope: fanservice, in which there are barely any. The first time you see boobs physics is cool, but it only happens three times in the story CG. You may find some characters to look hot in their alternate form, but you better enjoyed that 30 seconds ability animation over and over again!

Overall, Rebirth 1 fell short in every aspect of the game. Pick one aspect you want and make it good, damn it!

Haven't played Rebirth 2 and later games, so I might give it another chance later.

139017207.review:
Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 takes players on a delightful and nostalgic journey through Gamindustri, blending quirky humor, charming characters, and classic JRPG elements into an enjoyable gaming experience. As a fan of the original Hyperdimension Neptunia, I was thrilled to dive back into this revamped version, and it did not disappoint.

The game's premise revolves around personified console goddesses, each representing a major gaming console, engaged in a lighthearted battle for supremacy. The witty dialogue and numerous gaming references had me chuckling throughout the entire adventure, as the game cleverly parodies various aspects of the gaming industry.

Visually, the updated graphics of Re;Birth1 bring Gamindustri to life with vibrant colors and beautifully animated character designs. The character artwork is adorable, and the in-game environments are filled with intricate details, making exploration a treat. The addition of new character models and improved visuals enhances the overall immersion and creates a fresh experience even for those familiar with the original.

The gameplay mechanics strike a perfect balance between turn-based combat and strategic decision-making. Battles are engaging, with a wide range of skills and abilities at your disposal. The "Exe Drive" system adds a layer of excitement, allowing characters to unleash powerful special attacks, further intensifying the action. The user-friendly interface and accessible tutorials make it easy for newcomers to jump in and enjoy the game.

One of the highlights of Re;Birth1 is undoubtedly its memorable cast of characters. Each goddess possesses a unique personality, and their interactions and banter provide constant entertainment. The character development is commendable, as you witness their growth and bond throughout the game, forging meaningful connections with each of them.

Additionally, the inclusion of multiple endings and optional side quests provides ample replay value, allowing players to uncover hidden secrets and experience different storylines. It adds a layer of depth to the game, ensuring that you'll be spending countless hours in Gamindustri.

While Re;Birth1 has its fair share of strengths, it's not without a few minor drawbacks. Some may find the repetitive dungeon layouts and occasional grinding a bit tedious, especially during extended play sessions. However, the enjoyable narrative and charming characters compensate for these minor shortcomings.

Overall, Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 is a delightful and engaging JRPG that successfully revives the essence of the original game while enhancing it with updated visuals and gameplay mechanics. Whether you're a longtime fan of the series or new to the world of Gamindustri, this title offers a charming and entertaining experience that will keep you hooked until the very end.

Rating: 8.5/10

137244089.review:
It's crazy, I think this is the first game I've ever seen that's made up entirely of padding.

  This is one of the most tedious and agonizing RPGs I've ever played through.  Every aspect of its design is meant to waste your time.  Gameplay and story both.

  Gameplay-wise, it's a total slog, with no meaningful amount of strategy or planning required of the player.  The enemies are all totally basic, and every boss functions exactly the same.  They're all big, stupid HP walls that punch you really hard.  Since they're all the same, the strategy for all of them is also the same every time.  (That strategy being to get into triangle formation and punch them until they fall over.)  They aren't difficult, they just take forever to beat.  (Many of them also heal at the start of every turn they take, just in case you thought the game needed to take longer.)  Additionally, I'm willing to bet that at least 75% of this game's content is recycled, because all of the dungeons get reused, and so does every enemy or boss.  I'm not even exaggerating.

  As for the story, arguably the most important aspect of an RPG, it's absolutely rancid.  Pretty much all the characters are relentlessly irritating, and the overabundance of all the worst anime tropes in existence will likely leave you writhing in agony if you have any love for storytelling or good taste.  The humor is a groan-fest, the characters are all one-note (They also never shut up, and talk for ages about mindless garbage), and the overall plot is about as bog-standard as it gets for an anime RPG.  The concept of the game's universe being based on the console wars is stupid, but at least it could have had some potential and charm if the story decided to do anything interesting or funny with it.  "LOL THIS PLACE IS XBOX ISN'T THAT FUNNY" is about as deep as it gets, and I just think that's kind of pathetic.

  I have heard it said that "Neptunia isn't anything to write home about," but that's wrong.  Please write home about this game.  Write home to your loved ones and warn them never to play Neptunia.  I beg you, please spend your 15 dollars on a better game.

The developers were making a cute visual novel, but one day their drunken boss came into the office and said "We need to add battling mechanics because it fits the story", however the game was a day before release so the devs had to very hastily program an RPG system into this game. 

That's how this game feels anyway. While the story isn't anything groundbreaking, it is cute and simple. Get some loveable characters, throw in some funny dialog with a dash of fan service and you've got a story that will keep you entertained for a couple of hours. Unfortunately this game fumbles with every other part that isn't the story. While the gameplay has some interesting ideas, overall it is very boring. 136326103.review:
I understand the Neptunia series is VERY extensive, however. This is my first time playing a Neptunia game and I've never played any other Neptunia game before. So, please bear this in mind as I go through this review. Anyway let us begin the review. 

Let's start off with the story. You follow the story of a girl named ,Neptune, who lost her memory. Neptune is the CPU of Planeptune (which to my undestanding she's basically the leader of Planeptune or some kind head of State), though Neptune doesn't know this due to her memory problem. The story follows her as she goes on a journey to recover her memory. The story has okay writing its sometimes a hit or a miss. The story is mainly text in a visual novel style. But, unlike many visual novels in the story scenes you don't choose anything you just read, listen and follow the text. Overall, the story is very interesting to play through and is what keeps me invested.

The gameplay itself is mostly exploring different dungeons, you fight different enemies in those dungeons. The player may choose to do Guild quests, that takes place in the dungeons. There are some  quests that require the player to defeat a certain specific enemy that can only be found in a specific dungeon. When a quest is completed the player gains credits (in-game main currency), which the credits can be spent at the shop to buy new weapons and other gear to enhance your characters in your party. Fighting in dungeons can also allow your party to gain XP points. This is pretty simple stuff and is kind of nice touch.

However, the game has TONS of flaws. For starters the tutorial is useless, because the controls are based on PlayStation controls that haven't been translated into PC. So, not only the tutorial is useless, because it tells you how to play in PlayStation controls not PC. Also, this means that the controls like: camera movement, character selection, key shortcuts, character movement. etc. is complete garbage. So, you'd have to guess the controls I would recommend looking at the player made guides to help, because this is a must. 

Another flaw is that the game is FULLY AWARE OF ITSELF!!! this means I can only play for 1 hour before I lose my sanity. What I mean by this is that the characters are 100% aware they're anime characters in a anime video game. Hell even the main protagonist (Neptune), is fully aware she's the main character. (edit) Even a minor character named Historie is also 100% fully aware she's part of a franchise, when she mentions that she's the first character to use 'emoticons' of the franchise. The game one time made a reference to Star Trek and the characters were fully aware they were making that reference. Look I sometimes enjoy references, especially if its done right. But, with the game fully aware it is making that said reference and hell even the main characters are fully aware of it too. All that is just way too much for myself and does sometimes feel like the story feel like it's dragging along. 

Nevertheless despite all this though, this game does have a certain charm that does make me to give it an overall recommend. The characters for one are kind of attractive in a way and the story overall is kind of fun to follow. Even if it means that I'm playing 1 -2 hours every couple of weeks, I come back to it in the end. So, for those who wish to pick up this game, go for it. Be warned, though controls are absolute garbage and the game will deplete your sanity if you play it for too long in a day.

134994863.review:
[h1]Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1[/h1]

[h3]Reason To Play[/h3]
[list]
[*] Light-hearted story
[*] Fourth wall breaking MC
[*] A character to like by the end of game
[*] Seeing Villain Glow Up
[*] Console and different company/organization/group visualized as a character
[/list]

[h3]Expectation Before Playing[/h3]
[list]
[*] Turn-based Strategy
[*] JRPG
[*] Good team building
[*] Fun Game Mechanics
[*] Cool looking moves/skill/effects
[/list]

[h3]Reality after completing all the achievements[/h3]
[list]
[*] Completing the base game without all the achievement is a breeze.
[*] Work through game play to continue story, which is the good part.
[*] Simple turn-based strategy concept, nothing too fancy.
[*] Getting better equips is the way to go.
[*] Equips gets expensive at some point.
[*] To explore all the content in the game, level-up is the way to go.
[*] Difficulty spike at some point in the base game, and a bigger spike when trying to clear all the content.
[*] Can get grindy if you are looking to craft every single thing, and still kinda grindy to get all achievement.
[/list]

[h3]Pros[/h3]
[list]
[*]  Trust me, you won't see console, company, organization the same way after the game.
[*] Villain glow up, and I mean in both personality and appearance.
[*] Learn to strategize and achieve efficiency.
[*] Many items to craft, if you like getting every single thing.
[*] Cute naming of the move set for the characters.
[*] Comedy/parody.
[*] Fourth wall breaking characters to keep you company.
[*] Did I mention that you get complimented for clearing the game.
[/list]

[h3]Cons[/h3]
[list]
[*] Feel repetitive from the remake system or later maps, which kinda look the same.
[*] Spending more time than you would expect in order to get all the achievement.
[*] Did I mention that manual constant saving is a thing.
[*] RNG on item drop/finding is your friend if you are lucky, and your nightmare when you are unlucky.
[*] If you like the character's jumping sound, then you are lucky, else be prepared to be patient.
[*] Stuck with no event to trigger to continue the story on the next/new game cycle? Accepts the unobvious quest "The law of a hero".
[/list]

134209869.review:
If you're curious about the Neptunia series at all, I absolutely recommend this game.
No, seriously. Okay, I might've had some moments during my run where I felt like I was losing my hairs from my frustration at certain fights. 
Trust me, this is more apparent later on. A lot of the difficulty from certain fights comes from the goofy gimmicks like gradual HP recovery. Trust me, this gimmick is REALLY annoying on some of these fights and I hated it.
BUT!
Despite all this, did I enjoy it?
Yeah, I can say with full confidence I did. If you're ready to strap on your boots for an adventure like this I fully recommend it. This game had me smiling when I wasn't frustrated with the pretty wacky job at balancing. It was a fun ride story wise, and the combat system really had me interested in what was going on. Positioning people felt more prominent than most games I played and I really appreciated it.

10/10 minus a hair from the top of my head, I loved this game.

First thing is first, the PC port for MnK is not good, and I highly recommend playing this with a controller or on Steam Deck.

Aside from that, a lighthearted RPG game set in a world where it is something like a virtual world. The four main goddesses are basically the CPUs and the enemies and everything are often quite quirky. The game itself doesn't take itself super seriously, which I think contributes to the lightheartedness. Gameplay revolves around turn based combat in a party of 3 when you fight enemies. There are multiple ways to attack, include basic attacks, chained attacks, spells/abilities, exe drive, etc. I ended up grinding for quite a bit in game, and I found it was surprisingly fun.

Overall, fun game that I ended up enjoying quite a bit.

131569258.review:
🔵[b] Requires light tinkering [/b]

To fix resolution problem change the "high DPI settings" of the game executable:
- Find the game executable NeptuniaReBirth1.exe on your system (manage > browse local files).
- Right-click the executable, then select Properties.
- Switch to the Compatibility tab and click on Change high DPI settings, under "Settings".
- On the new window, under "High DPI scaling override", activate the checkbox: [✓].
- Select Application from the dropdown menu and confirm with OK.
- Click Apply, then OK on the Properties window.
- Launch the game.

- Game will start with mouse/keyboard controls (gamepad will not work). Navigate to options with touchscreen and change controls to gamepad.

Tested on: OnexPlayer Mini Pro 6800U

[list]

A good turn-based RPG. The only issue is how many enemies are just reskins and how some dungeons look exactly the same as others. 

The whole elemental stat attacks wasn't implemented very well and it's hard to tell what elemental strength and weaknesses enemies have, so it's usually better to overlevel your characters before big dungeon battles and ignore the elemental aspect. The Live2D character motions such as blinking and mouth movement during story dialogue is neat. Character costumes and special attacks are awesome. It'd be nice if the graphics were available in a higher definition with more detail, at least for future games or remakes. 

The story is simple but the comedy is decent. The game soundtracks are nice. Overall, a 7.5/10, would recommend to other weebs.

127521673.review:
I played Persona 5 Royal for about 10 hours and this (so far) for about 1. I've had about 10 times more fun with this.

At first this sounds somewhat absurd but hear me out. See Persona 5 is the sort of hyper-acclaimed media that it's fans and it's very nature, implies that you MUST acknowledge it's prestige and greatness. Only with the most cursory of a critical examination, thinly under the gleam of 90+ Metacritic scores, lies the most exquisitely polished excessively verbose turd that has brewed within itself Jenkem so strong that all but the most resistant get drunk on when they get near.

HYPERDIMENSION NEPTUNIA RE;BIRTH1 ON THE OTHER HAND is the JRPG equivalent of a B-grade campy horror comedy. There is no pretense, it's not trying to win awards or achieve mainstream success. Merely self-aware raunchy 4th wall breaking RPG comfort food filled to the brim with gaming references. If Lloyd Kaufman was 50 years younger and loved JRPG's and not Horror, this is what he would've come up with.

Ah Yes, The Game that started the Series... or Remake I should say!

First things first, I didn't knew Neptunia Series Existed since I was focused on other games, as I watched that Video about Characters Laugh to some Music, The First Character looked kinda cute, then Eventually I discovered the Series, so I went and Bought Neptunia Re;Birth1 and Finished it with True Ending, I can at least say, Neptunia Series and It's JRPG Genre helped me gain more exposure to Anime Genre. Alright, Time for Pros and Cons!

Pros:
- Simple and yet Fun Combat System
- Bunch of Game and Anime References... I mean, What do you expect.
- Silly, Yet Good Story to listen to.
- Grinding, Trust me Better be prepared to Grind a lot.

Cons:
- Difficulty Curve, The Game starts off easy, but Gets Harder during First Half, so I would recommend Grinding and using In-game Plan named "Weaken Enemies"

That's pretty much it for Cons.

Final Verdict:
Personally, I like this Game! with My Accumulated 60+ Hours, I would say It's Worth the Price, and It's even Better with The Sale. so.... Go get the Game, would ya?

125196332.review:
Honestly, I never heard of this game nor its anime for more than a decade until I modded my Left 4 Dead 2 game into an anime this year, I played that game for 10 years, and got attached to the Japanese anime 2 years ago. At first, I was so curious why it's one of the most popular anime mods in the L4D workshop (voicepacks, textures, UI, models and sounds) but then as I played for a while as the characters, I started to gain interest like saying to myself: "I wonder how the real game looks like and this looks like a cool anime show". So I bought the game and woah! It brought back my memories as a RPG player and a gamer as the characters literally represents the consoles and the genre is what I loved the most for many years. I love adventures! 

Speaking of the game, I truly agree with most players that grinding here is too much especially the first 25 levels. But after a few levels, it's somewhat became manageable. It's just you need the proper equipment and level to advance on the next stages, dungeons and defeat the bosses. Not only that, you need to read a lot of guides and tips so you could enjoy it! I'm so glad that these are available, special thanks to the Nep-Nep community! 

The only downside I see here are the character speeches during the cutscenes, there were some sentences that got cut off (I assume that the writer forgot to justify the text so that it could fit the text box) you can only hear the full sentence if you set the audio to English but if its in Japanese, you won't know what they are talking about. That's pretty much it, maybe in Rebirth 2 they have fixed these, so I would see it for myself. 

Gameplay... well, I like how simple it is, a turn-based RPG game. I'd say its a pretty neat game for a casual like me. 

So in conclusion, if you love anime and a game with cute, pretty and badass women. Then, Hyperdimension Neptunia is for you! I am proud to be a new fan of the Neptunia franchise, if it weren't for the L4D2 workshop I won't discover this classic gem. In contrast to other shows and RPG games, I believe the franchise is underrated, the game and the anime needs more love, guys! Let's bring Nep-Nep back to the spotlight!

Summary of my review:

Gameplay: 9 / 10
Soundtrack: 10 / 10
Visuals: 8 / 10
Story: 10 / 10 

Overall: 92.5 / 100 (Excellent)

Game difficulty: 7.5 (this is a RPG game that you must not underestimate. The simplicity doesn't mean its easy.)

120421361.review:
I actually enjoyed this game, but wouldn't recommend it to most other players, because it is a certain kind of ridiculous

This series is a very particular type of game that mixes turn-based RPG battles with long dialogue cutscenes that are almost like a visual novel. The characters are cute, and the whole world is a parody -- the name of the world is "Gamindustri", so it's all about video games. There's even a character named "Tekken" who attacks with fisticuff combos like a character from Tekken.

The humor in this game is occasionally great. More often, though, it's a cutesy self-referential fourth-wall breaking that may appeal to a certain type of player but probably not others. Which may well describe the whole game; you need to like the cutesy anime VN aesthetic and have patience for very long dialogue cutscenes because you like the characters. The characters are at least very pretty in the cutscenes, animated breathing so it's not just a static image. Likewise, the turn-based battles actually look pretty decent.

Unfortunately, it's all flash and no substance; in this case you're basically running many variations of the same few dungeons, fighting retreads and recolors of various enemies in mostly uninteresting turn-based combat interrupted by ridiculous sequences for your special moves like a FFVII summon. I mostly played this as a game to grind while watching Netflix, and indeed, grinding was required for me to beat the final boss.

Still, in spite of all the negatives, there is an undeniable charm to the game. And maybe I'm biased because the ending credits made me smile and filled my heart with joy. But this is a game for anime nerds who like video games, probably by anime nerds who like video games, and while the gameplay isn't very good alternating between grindy turn-based combat and long dialogue scenes, there's charm here for people who like that sort of thing.

It's sort of like a cake made by your five-year-old: It's not good enough that I'd recommend it to most people, but it's charming and I like it anyway even though the quality may be dubious. (And if this particular strange combination sounds appealing to you, maybe you'd like it too.)

120201988.review:
Lots to love and hate though I'm glad I stuck it out to the end for this classic/infamous visual novel / JRPG.

The good:
Excellent character designs and aesthetic.
Great music (though I would have preferred a tad more variety).
The special attacks look great.
Long but not too long. I finished it in 40 hours, and that was probably about right in retrospect.
If you're learning Japanese, this is good practice.
The free DLC characters and gear are extremely helpful in helping beginners navigate the game - at least until certain events.
This will run with no problems on a potato. Had no issue loading this up on my sleepy work laptop to grind on coffee breaks.
The Steam community is strong. I was able to button mash my way through the game up to a point, and then I had to find new strategies because enemies were regenerating way faster than I could chip away at them. Fans were generally sympathetic and offered some great advice.

The "ifs":
(Normally I have "The meh" here, but whether you click with the game is really dependent on you)
IF you enjoy cheesy trope-heavy anime humor, you will probably enjoy the dialog, voice acting and character interactions. I did.
IF you are into games and Japanese PC nerd culture, you will probably enjoy at least some of the references peppering this game. I did.
IF you are into min-maxing parties and don't mind grinding in bizarre ways, you'll probably like this. I...did not.

The bad:
Have you ever had food poisoning where you were puking and sh*ting your guts out at the same time?  That is how I felt about this overload of very counter intuitive systems, loot, EXE attacks, item use and UI in Neptunia. It's all set up to maximize a very weird kind of convoluted grind, and it took me out of the story.  I could really go on and on about this, but suffice to say it took way too long to get my head around things like Plans, shares, processors, discs and Lily Ranks and after I went to the trouble, I didn't like them.
The very concept of crafting items to increase dungeon difficulty so that you can grind more is NOT my thing. 
One or two huge difficulty spike boss battles that almost had me throwing in the towel.
I played with a mouse and keyboard and holy hell, that was awkward at times.
The story and world are nonsensical, and if you're looking for emotional investment in characters, go play a Trails game.

Verdict:
In the end, with the help of some good advice, Kei Jinguji and the Fairy Fencer DLC, I managed to overcome my anger, confusion and frustration with this game. And I'm looking forward to playing the sequels, cause in the end, the infectiously goofy characters won me over. But the world of Neptunia is certainly an acquired taste.

119213007.review:
Vintage chocolate chip cookies

Ingredients
150g salted butter, softened
80g light brown muscovado sugar
80g granulated sugar
2 tsp vanilla extract
1 large egg
225g plain flour
½ tsp bicarbonate of soda
¼ tsp salt
200g plain chocolate chips or chunks
Method
STEP 1
Heat the oven to 190C/fan170C/gas 5 and line two baking sheets with non-stick baking paper.

STEP 2
Put 150g softened salted butter, 80g light brown muscovado sugar and 80g granulated sugar into a bowl and beat until creamy.

STEP 3
Beat in 2 tsp vanilla extract and 1 large egg.

STEP 4
Sift 225g plain flour, ½ tsp bicarbonate of soda and ¼ tsp salt into the bowl and mix it in with a wooden spoon.

STEP 5
Add 200g plain chocolate chips or chunks and stir well.

STEP 6
Use a teaspoon to make small scoops of the mixture, spacing them well apart on the baking trays. This mixture should make about 30 cookies.

STEP 7
Bake for 8–10 mins until they are light brown on the edges and still slightly soft in the centre if you press them.

STEP 8
Leave on the tray for a couple of mins to set and then lift onto a cooling rack.

RECIPE TIPS
FREEZING THE BISCUITS
If you’ve frozen the biscuits, take them out and arrange them on a lined baking sheet. Once defrosted, pop them in a medium oven 190C/170 fan/gas mark 5 and heat for 2-3 mins to crisp up. Don’t leave them too long or they’ll dry out.
STORING DOUGH
You can keep the uncooked dough in a sealed container in the fridge for up to two weeks. Simply take some out, dollop on a lined baking tray and allow to come up to room temperature for 5 mins before baking

118844919.review:
The character designs they use for CGs and menus are absolutely beautiful

The combat system is both turn-based and very user friendly. For those wanting to have an easy time choosing your character's position on the battlefield prior to executing your action choices then you're in luck here. 

The combo menu is a neat feature in that it allows you to choose which types of attacks you wish for your character to chain in battle. This can also come in handy when needing to adjust for elemental/magic/physical resistances or weaknesses throughout the game.

The game offers plenty of tutorial screens and also allows you to revisit stages you've completed which enables you to both EXP grind and Quest grind to gain more credits(currency) to more easily purchase some decent equipment upgrades by the beginning of Chapter 2

Although the fairly basic level design and repetitiveness of returning to dungeons multiple times to complete side quests and grind could be a deal-breaker for some, I still feel the character designs and customizable  system help to compensate for this game's weaknesses.  

Overall, this game has me wanting to continue on through the main story progression and the combat helps to keep me fairly entertained.

115865887.review:
I have mixed feelings I'd like to share on this game. Since overall it was a nice, enjoyable experience that was generally bogged down by various hiccups. 

Pros:
-Fun characters with a laid back, enjoyable story.
-A nice variety of weapons that appear different in game/fights
-An awesome variety of outfits and accessories to make the characters truly feel customizable
-A nice variety of dungeons with an old school jrpg feel to them
-The grind feels productive in a satisfying way
-NG+ offered a nice way to unlock extra characters and 100% the game so I'm glad it was included
-Both weapon and costume designs were varied and pretty rad.
-The lily system was neat.
-The memes and 4th wall breaking kept the game fun for me. Mages as a character in general was really cool. 

Cons:
-The grind is a pain if you don't know which bosses to go farm at which points when you hit a wall in leveling
-The story can at times be cringe in the scripting (ie. the pudding being brought up as a core value for the protag constantly. It's just overused)
-Some dungeon DLC's can be considered predatory as I would argue they were necessary for 100% achievements. The grind would have been unacceptable without some of the dlc dungeon content. These should have been included in base game.
-I have a personal discomfort with a few of the loli characters turning into sexy women. It falls under "anime shit" I'm willing to overlook for the general game enjoyment.
-There were simply too many characters in this. With base game and all DLC characters, it felt like a quantity over quality situation.
-The plan system is annoying when it comes to certain aspects of the game and an over-saturation of grinding out certain items.
-Recycled assets are kinda rough.

115597469.review:
I just want to thank Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 for reinvigorating my interest in Japanese, (and Chinese, Korean) while introducing me to the Visual Novel genre. All of my VN's (40+ as of right now), and dozens of other East Asian games, were bought after I played this game nearly two years ago. And they have helped me in practicing those languages.

What makes this game immediately stand out is its over-the-top upbeat style. From the colorful drawings to the high spirit music, the game gives off the vibe of an amusement park. The core of the game are the dialogues, which are as fantastic as the rest. You have Neptune make fourth-wall breaking comments like "Why am I so glossy? Is it because I'm the main character?", but also remarks like "[Your name is] Noire? Seems like the name of someone with no friends." Every conversation made me laugh and i can't remember a moment I was bored.

Unfortunately, the actual game part of this game is less interesting. It's a turn based strategy, where you can move anywhere within a radius per turn. The animations were very satisfying to watch. But the game quickly becomes very grindy. You have to grind to get a good chance of beating the first boss (or do a little trick with a free DLC). Soon afterwards however, there's the option to make enemies weaker via one of the Plans.
The game has a lot of these "Plans", which unlock all kinds of things such as dungeons, different item drops (from the same enemies), different enemies (in the same dungeons), etc. You need items to get Plans to get dungeons to get items for other Plans to get new dungeons and items and so on. It's very cumbersome, even for RPG standards. Near the end of the game you again have to grind quests to increase Faith percentages in order to unlock different endings. This does not get much quicker with weaker enemies, as it mostly involves going back and forth between dungeons etc.

All in all, the first playthrough was an unforgettable experience, and I was playing multiple hours a day. If the combat and quests weren't so tedious, I would actually replay this game and their sequels for their dialogues and different endings. But sadly, I lost my patience for it.

114503888.review:
Hyperdimension Neptunia. I've been playing these games since the original released on the PS3 when I was in high school. Let's get one thing clear, this is not the original game. This is a complete remake of the original to make it play more in line with the rest of series. I have also played through this game on the PS Vita. As a remake, it's actually a pretty good one. A lot of the fluff was removed, and some of the more frustrating elements of the original game were reworked to be less annoying. Sadly some of what made the original unique was trimmed away. Many references, jokes, and plot points have either been removed, reworked, rearranged, or rewritten. However Rebirth does retain much of the personality and charm of the original. 

Now we move to the PC port side of things. Sad to say the PC port is terrible. The game suffers from issues such as menu prompts being Xbox controller icons even when keyboard and mouse is set as the controller input. When using a wireless controller, if you boot the game up before turning the controller on, the game will not register the controller is on and will refuse to use it as the input device. The game also suffers from resolution and frame rate problems, however they don't happen to me as much as others, so I can't really speak on those issues. Luckily people have found fixes and you can find them easily in the Discussions page for this game. The game also has some awful dlc that should have been in the base game.

I still recommend this game to any JRPG fans. especially if you like more light hearted adventures with some tongue and cheek jokes and references. This is a solid JRPG and is well worth it if you can handle the issues and grab this game and it's dlc on sale as the dlc adds some quality of life stuff to the game.

113872307.review:
Looking for something light hearted that pokes at the “old School” anime/manga… Well this might be what you are looking for.

You play as Neptune (The goddess of Planetunia). During one of the video game wars you where knocked out of battle and lost your memory. Now with the aid of some new found friends, you journey to find out who you are. Well that is how the story starts anyhow. The game pretty much forgets about that and focuses on 3 other story-lines with the occasional mention of your amnesia. Well at least it is not your normal boring amnesia story!

 As far is the graphics go, you are in no way treated to anything new. You are looking at PS3 style 3D with an anime cell shade color scheme. Do not get me wrong, there is nothing bad with this. Just if you are one of those individuals who focus on visuals first then story, you possibly will not like this game (Not that the story is strong either).

Each character is distinctively different and posses their own signature moves and personalities. The goddesses that you play ass have 3 different looks depending on what form they take. Then we have the monsters for this game. There is a good variety of creatures. The designers did an absolutely awesome job at creating some really creative creature types. There is one enemy who is a computer screen shot. Her avatar on the map is 2d with the front looking at her with text on the bottom and the back showing the back of the girl. Getting past the interesting monsters, you have a large set of standard creatures you would find in most other rpgs.

One thing I really did not like about this game was how separated the characters are. Each character has their specials and EX moves, however, only the CPUs have combo special attacks. To make matters worse, there is 1 group that gets a 3 person combo. So half the characters you end up with (all non CPUs) are left out of the fun. Not only that, 2 of them are the ones you get at the beginning of the game who are actually the main group! How sad is that...   

Looking at the levels, the game takes a huge nose dive on this. The map is very simplistic, you just move your character to where there is a spot that has something on it and click. You are transported to a super short repetitive location. The layout is extremely generic with wide open spots everywhere. You can literally walk around all monsters without facing a single one if you wanted to (The jump in this game is almost completely useless). I would not suggest it as the combat difficulty level spikes all over the place and you will definitely need to level up.

When you enter a fight, you have your typical RPG attacks. Your goddesses have the ability to transform and be much stronger. Once you get about a quarter through the game, you will notice that ALL story fights need to be done transformed or your are going to have a super difficult time. Getting back to the combat, you have 3 types of normal attacks each with a different intent. I went through the game only using 2 for the vast majority. After that you have your magic attacks, switch characters, use items, special attacks, and 2 types of team attacks.

Getting into the music. It is lighthearted and repetitive. Honestly that is all there is to it..! 

The game is partially voice acted. Most the scenes are text based with them mocking games, anime, and manga. The voices are good in both Japanese and English. However, what they say actually is the annoying part. So you might just want to stick with the Japanese because it at least sounds more realistic. 

If you are after a decent RPG that does not take itself at all seriously and does not have a complicated set of mechanics, go for this game. Be advised that like any RPG similar Final Fantasy, there will be lots and lots of grinding to get levels, drops, or Lilly ranks.

113825409.review:
I played the original on the PS3 when it came out. It seems in the intervening time, I forgot a lot about the game. Simplistic systems, grindiness and a lacklustre story mar this game for me.

- There is not much enemy or dungeon variety with lots of stuff being recycled. The game presents this in a sort of parodic send-up of the jRPG genre as a whole.
- The enemies and characters in the game are nicely presented for what they are. The character portraits used in the VN style dialogue sections of the game are animated which add a liveliness to the game.

- Overall, it was a little too grindy for me, and the battle system was a little to rudimentary compared to say Fairy Fencer F.

111246789.review:
I was hesitant to get this game, mostly because I'm not a waifu fan and.. I'm 52 so.. very weird for someone my age to get something like this without feeling very perv-y and I'm not into cutesy kid stuff.  I've been playing RPGs since Ultima zero and even before that in the early 1970s and I'm a huge Turn-Based Strategy RPG fan.

So.. this game is similar (to me) as Final Fantasy X2 (with Yuna, Riku, and Paine) complete with costumes and apparel, most of which don't do much to the character's stats (a few do).  I got Plutia (and glad I did) as DLC and her CPU form is questionably S&M (unexpected)..  Wondering if I should have got Peashy.. or Histore?

The game is very tongue-in-cheek tween-esque innocent innuendo referencing, but there's no nudity or sexual content depending on how you measure it,  and probably kid-safe to play, though some costumes may require a double-take at some suggestive camera angles that you'd find perhaps in a fashion magazine of late...

I probably could have beaten the game in under 30 hours but I grinded for a few days to unlock some content.  There's a TON of hidden content, and I completely missed the mini-CPU characters you can unlock which require you get your "Shares" above 50% (popularity based on mission-specific results).  I missed most of the costumes and never found a few ingredients (or reagents or components) for Plans to create certain items.  These were not easily apparent.  

The game is relatively easy, though Chapter 2 and 3 are probably the most difficult, especially learning the mechanics of it that's thrown at you with very light explanation.

Game is seemingly based on some OVA that I never watched, and this is sort of a restart of that effort like a reboot of a series.  I can see why it's somewhat popular to some who are into that kind of thing, and the characters reference "service" as in "fan service" as I had been an animator in Japan in the '90s and fans of the comic would want panty-shots or risque terms that would honestly be unlikely of girls that age saying anything like that ever (having met a few in Friendship Clubs).  I think the Japanese guys wish their girls would be that way, but I've never seen it; they'll be shy and cute but not also at the same time "suggestive", such is this anime-style culture that's huge there, and the birth of comics that it's deep in their culture now.

So is the game good?  Here goes:

Good:
Turn-based RPG similar to Final Fantasy VII, X, or X2 (nice)
Graphics are clean and interestingly well-rendered (even the DLC)  No expense was spared to match the anime.
Music is muted heavy metal with added bells for effect OR goofy cute music during intermissions.  There's only a handful of "songs" and everyone's EXE Drive super-attack move is the same song.  By hour 47 it starts to get old.  I wish each character had their own EXE Drive Finishing Move song, but overall well orchestrated.
Storyline is about friendship and unity but a bit vague as to why
Gameplay is interesting and mechanics are fairly slowly fed to you, increasing complexity
There's some okay strategy here but not overly tactical
The EXE Drive Finishing moves and SP attacks are interesting to watch
There's some anticipation as to if the girls are going to take their comments (such as face-full-of-eggplants by IFFY to stuff in Neptunia's mouth.. ahem) any further or not (they don't).
"Dungeon" areas are relatively small
Mini-boss fights are interesting and respawn as much as you like
Costumes are well-rendered if you can get them, both in their normal or CPU forms
Weapon types are interesting but fairly the same but are rendered nicely
Tons of unlockable content

The Bad:
Chapters 1-4 take 30 hours and Chapters 4-8 take about 8 hours
Tons of additional support characters are added after Chapter 6 when there's about 2 hours left in the game that I have no interest in.
You'll find you'll grind-for-cash and then be very overpowered after Chapter 4 just to buy a hair accessory
You'll never have enough cash to unlock everything you want to see or try out for everyone
The Support-Combo moves (2 characters attacking during the EXE-Drive Finishing) only works with Neptunia
Music and EXE-Drive Finishing moves can get tedious after a while
Storyline is about friendship and unity but a bit vague as to why (yep, again)
Side content and additional characters are unnecessary, only for extreme completists who want to spend 200+ hours unless you cheat and go online to read about strategies and tips to get the "True Ending" which is not obvious (again, you can probably beat this in under 30 hours like Epic Fantasy Battle V)

I'm not sure if the "Bad" things are really that bad, especially the last one; some people are really really into that kinda stuff.  I'm not sure what percentage of fans are going to spend hundreds of hours with this until you're ahego-drooling during long long grinds to get that hairband that does nothing.  Maybe.

The game IS good and it keeps you entertained.  The Japanese version uses flan instead of the Americanized "pudding" and there are a few mis-translations here and there for cultural understandability.  It is not so cute-sy that it is stupid for babies.  It is not so "hentai" that it's too perverted (er.. such is the actual translation of that) but a bit.. "cheeky" without going anywhere there in tween innuendo.  Maybe I wanted it to go further?  Just .. a little..  bad-"me" to think that.

Fans of Final Fantasy rejoice.  If you loved X2, this is for you.

Recommended.

PS.  Does the American version of Noire remind anyone of Nellie from Little House on the Prairie?

105440704.review:
If you enjoy this welcome to the rabbit hole

+nepnepnep

+I really enjoy the combat but it may not be for everyone. The loop of breaking monsters guards into doing massive damage just felt right to do, nothing too complex.I found myself repeating the same maps over and over just grinding every single character to lvl 99 for all the  level achievements and I wasn't bored because the combat was fun. 

+Combat wasn't the most braindead thing either. I think the biggest thing for the combat that people have to think about it the character positioning. You don't want your characters too near each other to get hit but you want them near each other to heal and all. It is also nice that we get to swap characters out and stuff like transforming our CPUs. The EXE drive was fun. Also a bonus is we can skip all animations by pressing l1 in this game so grinding wasn't annoying.

+Anyone into grinding will really enjoy this game. Maybe not the most engaging in terms of combat it was so satisfying to not only see big numbers but see my characters level up. The gameplay loop is really enjoyable and addicting in this sense. Again it may not be for everyone but dam for those who enjoy the loop, welcome to the neptunia rabbit hole. There are so many more games to be played.

+Stuff like the coliseum and dangerous enemies truly make the game more interesting and the loop more enjoyable. You can grind for the best gear of every character just for even bigger numbers and even then the coliseum can still whoop you if you aren't ready or you turned your brain off.

+Funny story. It was nice to see the story of neptune from amnesiac to becoming the all-powerful goddess again. The adventure was honestly fun and charming and the story being too comedic didn't take away from the development of the cast along with it. The game for the uninitiated is a parody on gaming and by all means the story does deliver on this regard. It is especially fun to see the references all over the story.

+The characters truly make neptunia what it is. They are all charming and funny and we all can have our favorites without hating the others. Also they are all girls. Noire is truly the goat character dam. In fact all the CPUs are very funny and charming in their own way. The banter between Vert and Blanc is really funny all the time as well. I like how each of the CPUs are unique in their characters. They are all tropes honestly but dam they are well-executed. In fact they play into their trope so well they even know they are tropes really. The other characters like IF and Compa too aren't the blandest of characters and overall the cast again is what makes the series.

+Yes this game only has girl characters and yes there is a lot of fanservice. Not even 5 minutes into the game you are greeted with some questionable fanservice that makes you have to look around your surroundings to make sure you are truly alone. 

+It was nice to see classic video game characters in a parody sense. The mario and snake parodies kill me even if it's just small text that appear in the overworld. In fact not just the overworld, the entire game is filled with video game references and its really really fun to play I Spy and find them.

+Very well voice-acted. It was fun to hear the dialogue and interactions between the characters. The execution of both dubs is great. Neptune's VA is great on both languages but Noire having the same voice as Makise Kurisu in Japanese doe. I found myself really playing out every dialogue just to hear them talk and its a bonus that you can open the text history and have them repeat some specific text boxes.

+The soundtrack is filled with bops. I am a fan of all the tracks as they set up the mood pretty well. It is hard to take some parts seriously even if the soundtrack is in a serious tone since it is still a neptunia game but regardless a great soundtrack.

+The plan system is truly unique and fun to tinker around with. Very rewarding and fun to find the different things you can make with it. Although these may seem tedious to those who are not the biggest fans of grinding, I found myself trying (and failing) to get every plan in the game unlocked.

-Dungeons didn't feel so well-designed. A lot of the dungeon skins just felt the same honestly, just the same old cave or something of the sort.

-Needed multiple playthroughs to get all the plans (common problem in HDN R;B) and frustrating all the time when you lack memory for the plans you want.

This game is definitely a rabbit hole that welcomes all degenerates.

105144859.review:
If you enjoy the characters and the story of anything else Neptunia, this is a definite yes.
If you don't, it's a probable no.

Most of the core RPGs in the series feel very asset swapped and have similar dungeons, monsters and even combat to a point. Had I JUST played Cyberdimension Neptunia and Virtual Stars before this the balance would probably be tipped more towards a yes - as they all have very different combat styles. Coming off the back of just playing Superdimension Neptune VS SEGA Hard girls the balance is probably only just a YES because they are notable similar in so many areas. Music. Dungeon layout. Combat mechanics (though a few key things differ). Even progression to an extent. (Think 4 Goddesses in 4 areas of dungeons v 4 console generations).

Nothing is done poorly, but neither is any of it exceptional. I do give credit for the amount of outfit pieces you can get for every character, and thankfully the best stuff stat wise isn't a complete mismatch (even if it isn't quite perfect). It probably says more about my expectation of gaming that I almost would expect most of them to be pay walled.

Ultimately this is a YES. Buy this.

Though I would definitely recommend either not playing two of the core RPGs back to back - and instead playing the other genres or instead, having a break between the games so you're not over familiar with a lot of what is in game.

This game is certainly nothing if not extremely anime. I readily admit that was the main reason I decided to get this game despite not really being that good at the RPG genre, but I got a lot more enjoyment out of this game beyond the anime and fanservice factor. Thrashing out against the enemies of this world turned out to be extremely satisfying, especially when doing so with characters that do not look like they belong in your average RPG party. I guess what made this so enjoyable despite difficulty spikes in some areas is the fact that it's far from your average RPG game; it's as if the devs knew that's what they were making in the process of creating it. The fourth wall was practically non-existent, half the adventurers turned out to be "misadventurers" who had no idea what they were getting into, the mostly consistent dungeon layouts made navigation pretty easy, especially when I have trouble keeping focus when playing games, the enemies were comically outlandish in appearance and even more so in their attacks, the plot was so absurd and it was pretty obvious you weren't meant to really make sense out of it in the first place (and I apologize if that sets off anyone who played the original ps3 rendition and found the plot progression in there more satisfying than this rendition), and the combat system was quite simple to get the hang of. The whole thing turned out to be quite a fun experience that I simply could not put down until I had cleared it for the first time. If you're looking for an RPG game that for the most part is nothing like what you would expect of an RPG game, this is certainly for you. I do of course have a few complaints about this: The controls feel very counter-intuitive when playing on a keyboard, but luckily I had a controller I could rig up to have something more comfortable. Despite my personal view that the character's lines and voices sounded much more entertaining when set to English, many of the visual novel-esque cutscenes did not play any lines while the language was set to English, but that's only a minor gripe with the parts that take place between the gameplay. Because I find myself being such a meticulous completionist, it pained me to come to terms with the fact that I couldn't unlock everything of interest on my first playthrough, but thankfully everything I unlocked in my first could be available when all the 'unlocking space' was reset when starting a new game cycle created from that completion. All in all, a great experience with a few bumps in the road, as I anticipated it would be.



(And on a side note, while I shared my screen so some of my friends could watch me play it, we found that many of the interactions between characters in the cutscenes seemed to be very similar to our own interactions and mannerisms, which made us both laugh and cringe)

101019125.review:
Not revolutionary, but decent. The characters and dialog are cute and fun to watch, and the plot is pretty tongue-in-cheek. Production values are good enough, and there's plenty of content. I like the "plan" system which lets you "craft" upgrades to dungeons in addition to items. It never feels like there's a shortage of things to do.

Combat is a bit mindless in-the-moment, but it moves fast and is flashy and the game does add systems+complexity to your build as you go. Mindless-but-flashy isn't necessarily bad, it's a decent game to turn your brain off. Grinding is needed but it goes very quick. My only real criticisms of the combat are that it doesn't do a good job of indicating what level you're expected to be to fight given foes (especially since plans add strong minibosses to areas of otherwise-lower-level enemies), and fiddling with your character position to hit multiple enemies with a basic attack combo hurts the pacing.

100445249.review:
As a fan of anime and rpg, this is a no-brainer for me. I paid full price for it and I would happily do it again because I really enjoy the games from Idea Factory and Compile Heart. The best way I can summarize this game is that it is an anti rpg game. What I mean is everything that people think of when it comes to high quality is thrown out of the window. 

First, the fourth wall breaking is very out of place in most rpg's but it feels right at home with the antics by Neptune (who from henceforth shall be called nep-nep) and company. As others have pointed out that it is basically meme material and I do not see a problem with that as long as the player knows what they are getting themselves into. Every cutscene I found myself laughing at not only the absurdity of some of the dialogue/situations but also the parodying of one of the most rage inducing enviroments which is the console wars.

Second, to the reviewers that complain about the use of alternate colors, tedious gameplay and the like, that is the point of the game. Again, it's a parody of rpg's which is even stated by nep-nep in 4th wall breaking dialogue. It is also a homage to the old 8-bit and 16-bit rpg's where they had to do a color change because of the lack of memory size in the cartridge. Personally, I find not only a nostalgia feeling, but I can not help but chuckle at the same things I always questioned of those games, to be brought up by the game itself.

Finally, while I do not like the grind as much as I would other games, it's a necessary evil being that it is the norm for most of the retro games. At some point (the ng+ for me) it gets boring going through the game powered-up from the game before but it also allows more content to be viewed/played, items to be crafted and if it matters to you, achievements to be completed. 

The price isn't bad at all for the standalone game, but if you are really on the fence about it I would wait for a bundle sale or humble bundle to pick it up. There will always be people who are not happy with a game (variety is the spice of life) but if you enjoy anime, roleplaying games, laughing at in-game antics and 4th wall breaking dialogue then I would humbly suggest trying this game.
