99636900.review:
[h1][b]Visit [url=https://www.sinicalanimenetwork.com/post/hyperdimension-neptunia-re-birth-1-review]Sinical Anime Network[/url] to view this review with pictures and alot of other reviews and anime content![/b]

[b]Follow us for more reviews at:  
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/vnislife]Visual novel, JRPG, Anime Steam Group[/url] [/b][/h1]

[b]Story:[/b]
Game Industry, the world in this game has been for centuries ruled by four goddesses. Neptune, Noire, Vert, and Blanc. But since humankind can remember, the four goddesses have been entrenched in a long Console War, a war that took place to decide who will be the one to rule over the whole of Game Industry.

During this longstanding battle, a new figure inserts herself in the matter and takes advantage of the situation for her own purposes, getting rid of Neptune who is the most dangerous threat to her. With a combined effort of this new enemy alongside the other three goddesses, Neptune is defeated and thrown down from the goddess palace sent crashing into a nearby forest.

A young lady named Compo saw a shooting star-like object falling from the sky into the nearby park and decides to check it out. When she arrives she finds an unconscious girl at crash site.
After bringing Neptune back to her apartment and nursing her we find out that Neptune has amnesia and is clueless as to what happened. This starts an adventure to find clues and recover Neptune's memory to know who she is and to understand the events that happened that day.

To undergo this mission, we explore dungeons, forests, caves, and other places and dimensions. We control the movements and actions of Neptune and her new friend Compa to fight an ever increasing amount of monsters that have started appearing in Celestia. 

Eventually, they come across a culprit named Arfoire who seems to understand what is happening. Their travels take the girls to Lastation, Leanbos, and Lowee where they meet the goddesses under different circumstances and it appears as though they are all involved in the scheme of Arfoire, who also brought trouble to them. 
Slowly Neptune gathers more and more allies during her travels and new friends ready and willing to help her in this dire situation. A friendship, that is bound to rewrite the book of history in a new light.

[b]World Presentation & Visuals:[/b]
The world is large floating island separated into 4 areas for each goddess. The diversity in the environments are varied between natural areas such as mountains, forests parks, to industrial buildings, old factories, and even ones that look dimensional. The environments match well to the specific city that they are in with the exception of Basilicoms. Each goddess has their own unique theme for their city.

Planeptune is the most advanced city of all with a very modern layout and presentation. 
Laststation is a industry-driven city, were large factories and smoke seems to be the standard.
Leanbox is an atypic-looking city with a specific style of buildings and the look is very unique.
Lowee is a nordic style city, the buildings are round-shaped and modern-looking buildings adapted to cold weather and keeping one warm.

The character sprites are all drawn well with lots of diversity in their poses and facial expressions. The artwork really expresses each girls emotions perfectly and it really adds to the effect in comedic moments. Each girl only has one outfit for these scenes, but you can unlock new appearances from plans that you find from the second chapter onwards as well as various designs from purchasable DLCs.

The CG's are high quality with vivid details that are well highlighted which represent the specific area they are in appropriately.
Additionally, we have a feature that unlocks CG's and music in a Museum. This opens up by completing stories and unlocking new chapters.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
This is a Dungeon JRPG in which we can set up a team of three characters as the active team plus three additional that play the role of background support characters. While we battle different kinds of foes we can change characters by switching the main character from the frontline to the character in the background adapting to the combative needs, or preference if wanting to level up a specific character's Lili ranks.

Once we know that Neptune is actually a goddess she ends up transforming and we can use her full potential in battle likewise to the other three goddesses and two additional goddesses available in DLC's. 

The battles are turn-based, either fighting a horde of small NPC's or a single boss monster that is much stronger and more difficult to defeat. There are different types of elements involved where goddesses, friends, and monsters each have their own element. Adapting your team to be strong against specific elements is a necessity or the given monsters will remain too strong.

On an additional note, upgrades can be bought and unlocked by plans that you collect through the game. Once a plan is obtained, you can purchase the item in the shop to upgrade characters. Need a stronger sword? Collect the materials to unlock the plan and buy it! 
This feature is a really neat one with a good variety of options for each character. An added bonus is that you can gather materials for plans that change the appearance of a character. As you tend to get invested in the characters, this is a huge bonus where you can personalize them and well worth the effort.

[b]Voices and Music:[/b]
The game is partially voiced, events are not all voiced sadly but the voiced ones are outstanding with top tier voice actresses. There are frequent comical and funny quotes which made me laugh and smile over and over again. I can not say enough positive remarks about the voice acting when it was present.

During the fights the game is fully voiced. Attacks are named and voice quotes are added for a few of the special attacks from each character which I found to be very neat. This helps to further establish the personality types of the girls.
The game is accompanied by an amazing opening song and also enjoyable background music. I really did enjoy the opening and could see how many YouTube reviewers would want to include it somewhere in their video review as it fits this game perfectly.

[b]Routes:[/b]
We don't have any choices in the game that would change the story, but we do have a choice between two different routes. I wouldn't call one route a bad route since both routes are good in their own right. But we have only one true ending. 

The routes are decided by certain key points to attain and watch over. If we don't reach the necessary points requirements we won't be able to achieve the true route. Still, I really do recommend doing the playthrough twice for both routes because both endings are a must-watch.

[b]Achievements:[/b]
The game provides different achievements of accomplishments, some of them require quite a few hours of gameplay since they are thought to be complete. The toughest of them being the millionaire achievement which is not easy to complete even with the additional DLC's.

[b]Overall Impression and Thoughts:[/b]
Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth 1 is definitely a great JRPG that has super cute characters, amazing opening and ending songs, nicely voiced parts, and a good deal of humor mixed inside fun combat. There is a noticeable grind, but the story is engaging and helps motivate you to make it through the grind of monster hunting.

I did enjoy it from start to end, and of course, once we fought our sweat off, why not finish the day with some delicious pudding?  Neptunia Rebirth1 without a feast of pudding? Unthinkable! The love of pudding for the main protagonist is definitely addicting.

Additional DLC's evolve the game even more by adding new characters, higher max level, new epic monsters, additional dungeons, and items to unlock. With or without the DLCs I can highly recommend this title for it's enjoyable story, characters, and combat.

96935885.review:
Just recently getting into the Neptunia series after buying the bundle on a steam sale back in 2018, I could say I have become a fan and cannot wait to play the other titles.  

Neptunia Re;birth 1 is a very lighthearted, comedic, and cute turn based JRPG with a well written story that is told through a traditional visual novel style. You follow the adventures of Neptune, a CPU (in this universe, a goddess) of the nation of Planeptune and her friends she meets along the way. The game features and entirely female party where each character is based off a game, game console, or game company. Everything in this game is a reference or homage to the game industry (which is also the name of the world the game takes place in). 

The game is a turn based JRPG but does not play like a traditional turn based JRPG. To elaborate, when you enter a battle there is a small ring which is where you can move party, and there is also a blue box on the ground that shows where and what your attacks will hit, this makes for very versatile turn-based combat. There is also a system called EXE Guage that builds up by the amount of hits your party deals on an enemy and how much an enemy’s attack lands on you. Upon reaching 1 bar in the EXE gauge, you can unleash an ultimate attack that each has very eye-catching animations for going ham on an enemy. Through my journey unlike in most other JRPGs where after a certain point most items are useless, that is not the case here in Neptunia. Items will be your best friend throughout most of the game. I cannot recall a boss where I did not use a portion of sorts. The game is also NOT open world, everyplace you adventure to is a small dungeon with quite a lot of monsters and usually one or two strong monster which is an optional mini boss that you must slay for guild quests. Although the game only has dungeons each dungeon is fun to explore, item search, and fight the monsters that are unique to said dungeon. The one flaw that is a turn-off for many newcomers (like me) is the game has way too much grinding for each boss. I got through the huge level spike bosses by means which I cannot discuss in this review.  

You can pick the game up on Steam and Ps Vita (but I don’t know why you would). There is also a remake coming soon for PS5 exclusively called Neptunia ReVerse which I would recommend picking up if you have your hands on a PS5. 

 

For the ratings: 

Story/writing - 7 

Graphics/performance - 7 (it isn't great for today's standards but for the time it was made, it is not bad at all. 

Gameplay – 8 

Overall score – 7.3

If you are like me and this series flew under your radar forever - you might be in for some fun!

The game is a mix of visual novel and turn-based JRPG. I say VN because some of the Event scenes can feel a little lengthy.  Also there are CGs. The battle system is pretty straight forward. Mechanics/UI features are explained clearly. I haven't finished my first playthrough yet but the story appears to be pretty straight forward. Without revealing too much:
 [Bad Thing] happens and now you have to find [things] to [undo Bad Thing]. And you pick up strays to add to your party as you go.
The writing is pretty fun because the game is pretty self aware/4th wall breaking at times.  So if you don't enjoy Deadpool or a good pun the writing might not be for you....  But the girls are cute????

Anyway, when I had picked this up I had a hankering for turn based combat but didn't want to replay my stand-bys.  This has been a delight and I picked up the next two games in the main series.

94310059.review:
What can I say that hasn't already been said?

This game is a badge of shame to wear proudly, because I don't care what they say, it's fun as hell. It's amazing, in a way - it's a game FULL of some of the worst things in gaming that manages to somehow make them charming (at least, to some of us) rather than grotesque:

- cringe-y hypersexualized female character design
- awful sex jokes
- forced memes (that have successfully matured into just "memes")
- "dungeon" "design"
- like, the dungeons are mostly just straight paths, and are incredibly small
- dude, most of the dungeons are literally just copies of other dungeons with different enemies
- perhaps the most Horse Armor DLC in a game (or game series) EVER
- grinding beyond belief (although it's the surprisingly fun nature of the combat that saves it here - the controls are mostly excellent, and everything is very slick)
- cool plot...for a clown to write. at the circus

Even I'm not sure exactly why I like this game so much, but certainly part of it is Compile Heart's weirdly indie-feeling nature. They make these games that seem fairly big and professional at first glance, but as you play, you quickly notice all the quirks of having a relatively low budget. It's like a team of amicable goofball perverts got together and said, "hey, let's make a game!" There's a general feeling of "being in on the joke" while playing - they know you know, and you know they know you know. "Chill, and enjoy our ridiculous, well-polished trash. Hang out with your dumb, fun anime friends. Repeat to yourself, 'it's just a show, I should really just relax'." It is beyond silly, and embraces it. The content that is here, gameplay wise, is also polished, and quite slick. There's just not a lot of it that's not copy-pasted. It's never wonky or glitchy, just...light.

So, in summary: needs more Nep-Nep. Yup, I said it.

93694490.review:
Overall, Re;Birth 1 is an excellent entry point into the Neptunia series, it does a great job of introducing the Gamindustri setting, the four main goddesses, as well as other recurring characters and tropes. If you have any interest in Neptunia you might as well start here, as the game is only 20 hours long (including the true ending) and this remake provides a very smooth experience, with only some minor grievances.

A little bit of a history lesson, the first Hyperdimension Neptunia game was released on the PS3 in 2010 and it was arguably one of the worst JRPG's ever made, it still sits at only 45% on Metacritic, due to its very poor gameplay choices and performance. But it did have some very cool characters that we still love today. It wasn't until the third game (Hyperdimension Neptunia Victory) that the series was finally a success, and then Idea Factory decided to remake the whole trilogy on Victory's engine, and the Re;Birth games on Vita and PC are the result of that effort. The gameplay was vastly improved, but the games share a lot of assets as an unfortunate side effect of using Victory as a base. It's also worth noting that large parts of the story in Re;Birth 1 were rewritten to make the characters less antagonistic towards each other.

Just like other Idea Factory games, it's a visual novel/dungeon crawler hybrid. The combat is turn-based, but you can move within a radius on your turn. You take position and either execute combo attacks, or use skills which range from simple heals and buffs to powerful attacks with epic anime cutscenes. Characters can transform into their "goddess" forms Sailor Moon/Power Rangers style, which boosts their stats and gives access to exclusive attacks. The mechanics are easy to learn and offer just enough depth. And all animations can be skipped so the combat is never a chore.

The problem with Re;Birth 1 specifically is that it has an inverse difficulty curve. One of the earliest bosses in the game ([spoiler]Black Heart[/spoiler]) is a massive difficulty spike and probably the toughest challenge across the whole trilogy, and unfortunately does require some grinding and strategic use of items. The first half of the game is overall a bit of a slog with spongy enemies and prolonged battles. But once you unlock EXE drives the difficulty completely evaporates and all you do is spam rush attacks to fill up your EXE gauge and then spam your strongest EXE drive. Later games in the series are better balanced, so don't let this discourage you.

The game also has only 3 party member slots unlike 4 in every other Neptunia game, which limits your combat options a bit. It's especially disappointing since there are so many playable characters, including many DLC ones. And speaking of DLC, don't turn on the Plutia and Peashy DLC on your first playthrough, these characters are from Victory/Re;Birth 3 and their HDD transformations are supposed to be big plot twists, which this DLC will completely spoil for you. It's fun to play as them in Re;Birth 1 but they don't have any story scenes, so you won't be really missing out.

You've probably heard of other remakes and re-releases of the first Neptunia game, so let's take a look at how this PC version stacks up against them. The Vita version is completely superseded by the Steam release, as the latter has way better graphics and more content. Re;Birth 1 Plus on the PS4 has some minor improvements which weren't backported to the PC release, mainly the 4th party member slot and a couple more guest characters. And then the recently released Neptunia ReVerse on the PS5 is again the same game, with slightly [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CMbP42TNRNA]improved graphics[/url] (but way too much bloom) and a [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8fYbJbp3iIg]fishing mini-game[/url]. ReVerse is indeed the definitive edition with technically the most content and features, but it's $50 and PS5 exclusive, and I wouldn't say it's worth it for such minimal changes.

93175387.review:
This game is trash, basically the only positive thing about it is the cute characters. Gameplay is bottom of the barrel, you're forced to grind and the only relevant strategy is to spam super attacks and spam rush attacks in order to build up your super meter. You end up having a decent amount of characters to use by the end but for some reason you get around half of them only in the last 1/4 of the story and they're all shit compared to characters you already as well as possibly underlevelled if you grinded so there's no reason to use them. In general the only characters worth using at all are your four transforming characters as well as Compa who serves as a dedicated healer. You can buy DLC characters as well who are apparently overpowered and just breeze through the game if you want which doesn't really sit well with me but whatever. 

You'll be going through different dungeons which are all copy pasted version of previous dungeons and they all have incredibly boring level design so you won't be enjoying seeing them again. You'll also be fighting the same pallet swapped basic enemies and dungeon minibosses over and over again to gather materials and to grind exp. The way progression works is basically you go through the story until you get thrashed by a boss, then go back to a previous dungeon and grind until you can destroy it in 3-5 exe attacks. 

There's also  the plans system. You use materials from minibosses and basic monsters to activate plans which then impact gameplay. You have plans for more or less everything including gameplay settings, items, costumes, equipment, changing the minibosses and items found in dungeons and even adding entirely optional dungeons. This is an absolute chore to get through, you'll want to have a browser window open with a spreadsheet or guide because there's no way to track which monsters drop the items you need for a plan and then you'll be going around killing the same shitty mobs over and over again hoping they drop what you need. You can probably go through the entire game without touching the plans system since grinding is the only thing that matters. You get enough good items and weapons without it and the system plans are the only ones that really make a difference since they can change the difficulty or give you cheaper exe attacks.

If you're going into this game hoping for a good story and interesting characters then look elsewhere. The game itself is some sort of parody so the story might as well not exist and every character can be summed up with a sentence. The writing itself isn't very good or funny, the whole thing is like a trashy anime. Once again the characters are very cute but if you're considering buying this game because they appeal to you you'll be much better off viewing other material rather than playing this game.

HyperDimension Neptunia Rebirth 1 es un VideoJuego basado en las parodias de la industria de los videojuegos, es una re-imaginación como reinicio de la trilogia original de PS3 basandose en la jugabilidad JRPG de MK2 y Victory, originalmente este juego fue lanzado como exclusiva de la Playstation Vita junto con 2 ReBirths más y 4 Spin-Offs usando motor de Fellistela, la historia es algo sencilla pero efectiva.

Lo Bueno:
- Buena Música
- Personajes muy carismaticos (al punto que digas, mi waifu 4 life)
- Jugabilidad JRPG entretenido y son salteables las animaciones para ahorrar tiempo
- Doblaje en Ingles muy memorable (rara vez que pasa en esta clase de juegos japos como Disgaea)
-  Si eres del gran conocimiento estaras como oh entendi esto

Lo malo:
- El port a PC esta mal optimizado, lo peor que te puede pasar es un softlock en combate siendo un bug rompe juegos que sigue presente 
- No hay traducción al español para algunos puede alejar los que no saben el idioma (aunque no creo que sea el unico en quejarme)
- No hay configuración grafica, algo fatal de los requisitos que pide
- En algunas escenas en el doblaje al ingles no estan dobladas por razones desconocidas, muy por parte el director del estudio que eso se le llama flojera

En conclusión: Es un juego bastante divertido, si es tu primera vez vas a estar en un buen reto que se requiere mucho muchisimo tiempo y dedicación, los dlc son opcionales y el capitulo 2 del jefe esta p-censurado- con ganas, asi que ten una buen pudin (Flan) y adentrate en este mundo de Nepita y sus amigas. 8/10

90211350.review:
HyperDimension Neptunia Rebirth 1 is a game that consists of a bunch of characters, none of them taking themselves seriously, entire game is a parody. Unfortunately, the game misuses this to create characters that are very hollow and lack any kind of motivation - completely the opposite of what I like in JRPGs.

The gameplay is weak - only at the last chapter was there anything resembling a 'RPG' where you had some decent set of choices and options. Otherwise it is almost always a very algorithmic action game. As others have pointed out, it is also very heavily grindy, and it is also aware of it - it does give some options to make it a little easier to grind.

The story makes no sense. Further, the comedy didn't always hit - it fell flat many times.

For a JRPG the music is disappointing. I always have high expectations for music in this genre, and nothing stands out in rebirth 1.

In my opinion, this game doesn't deserve an 'overwhelming positive'. You may still enjoy it though, if you are not expecting any complexity in gameplay or some sense in the story.

88285004.review:
I really wanted to like Neptunia, but the experience is really hollow, this is a niche product with very bad gameplay.
Pros
+Cute girls
+Nice art 
+Fun dialogue, breaks the 4th wall many times, lighthearted and cute
+Game has an integrated skip animation button to make fights faster
+Japanese voices are included, and you can toggle them anytime
+Good Music, albeit it gets reused quite a bit in dungeons...
+Money is hard to come by until the endgame, and you end up using items a lot to heal, which is a rare sight in RPG's these days, which shower you with more than enough resources

Cons
-Very basic gameplay, you go forward and attack enemies, defend, use items, not much strategy needed.
-Bestiary is a joke, can't see enemy experience and credits drop.
-A lot of reused assets, way too many recolored enemies, reused dungeons (as in the whole dungeon gets copy pasted and renamed), reused dungeon textures to make a "new one", this gives the game a very cheap feeling and an overall feel of 
 the game having a budget of a mcdonalds menu.
-Tutorials ingame are functional, but many things aren't explained, like how your characters have passive skills, along with Lily skills they can give to partners.
-You get a lot of characters really late in the story, giving you not much chance to try them, since you probably don't have gear for them, and they come at predefined levels, you will be better off with your usual party.
-Endgame is very grindy, from max level 99 to 999, you can expect a good bunch of hours just leveling, then getting items to unlock enemy add plans to challenge harder stuff.
-Remake system is more of an annoyance than anything, you need to gather items to research plans that either give you gameplay bonuses or new items in the shop, this is just a time sink, usually the items required are simple to get but the sheer number of new items makes it very annoying to go get the required items.
-A lot of DLC, most of it is very trashy and should have been added in updates
-DLC characters are much more powerful than what you have in vanilla, they hit way too hard and make the game a joke
-All shops are the same, same with cities, guilds, etc.
-You don't explore the world, you have an overview of the whole world and press on icons.
-The CPU diary on each city has like 4 entries each, which are very short too, don't expect extra lore or anything relevant here.
-Some dungeon plans are in hidden treasures in random spots, which also have random loot, this is very annoying.
-ALL of the bosses you will end up approaching the same way no matter your party composition, use Rush attacks, build EXE gauge, unleash EXE attacks, rinse and repeat.
Overall I only recommend it for people who can ignore the really bad gameplay and reused assets, and want to see the story through, because the gameplay is just that bad.
5/10, don't buy if you have good taste in RPG's...

87867214.review:
The concept seems fun on the surface but the game has some glaring issues mechanically that I cannot abide. You're expected to somehow know the difference between "boss fight you're supposed to lose because story" and "boss fight that you have to win" without any semblance of an indicator. (If you've played this, I'm referring to the first encounter with Arfoire.) Then in the optional dungeons (I assume they're optional as they're only unlocked via a function called "Plans" and don't seem to be required for migrating the story) which I assume are for grinding up your level to deal with upcoming bosses, there's stupid things to deal with like having multiple variations of the enemy (namely the rabbits in the factory) that all have the exact same field model. Now, this by itself isn't an issue but there is an INSANE variation in their strength. One of them I can kill at my level in about 2 hits, some others will 2 hit *ME*, and for whatever reason you have no way of knowing you've encountered one until you're getting wiped out and the flee command is doing nothing but wasting turns... all this making the player lose valuable progress because several of these dungeons, including the one thats the worst offender of this don't have a place where you can save. I wanted to like this game but... jeez.

TL;DR Too many mechanics working concertedly against each other, avoid if you value time and/or sanity. >.>

Buy this game if you have taste and are smart enough to read this review!

[i]I bought a limited edition version and was disappointed as it didn't include all the dlc! The box was nice and the artbook was a scam! It was tiny!!!! Moral of this tangent is buy digitally and wait for Gabe to give us a sale! xo [/i]

So back to normal... Here's some Pro's, Con's and Summary enjoy! (I use too many !!!)

[b]Pro's[/b]

- Meaningful and pointless conversations 
- Interesting story
- Blanc 
- Full controller support
- Genuinely funny moments
- Trading Cards, Steam Achievement and worthwhile Point Shop items
- Pudding had to be explained!
- Chian (an NPC) is voiced by the same actresses who voices Rukia of Bleach!

[b]Con's[/b]

- No auto message
- No auto save (you can manual save np just like old school games)

[b]Summary[/b]

Early on its best to stick to main story and quests. This is because you can easily unlock dungeons early on which are way too strong to beat. So at least save before you go in them.

When you first meet Noire it can get quite difficult. My advice is to go to the shops and equip good gear early on. Then check your combo setting, get it set up and ready. That means doing a few battles and getting the EXE to level 1 at least. You may also need to stock up on good items as well.

85268346.review:
Good Game, basically it's pretty much like Factorio.

No seriously, it really is. Because you spent almost all your time grinding and not having enough of what you need. They really don't lie when they say it's extremely customisable to your play style (like Factorio.) And (much like Factorio) you will happily sink many hours of your life away into it. And if even someone like me can finish it on normal difficulty, I imagine you will also be able to.

Downsides:
- No automation. Which really kind of sucks for those moments when you'll spent three hours grinding in dungeons only to get knocked out by the level boss. (Use your save files wisely, and save whenever possible.)
- There aren't any trains.
- The story is surprising, relaxed, unexpected, and actually really good. It's so good that the actual gameplay gets in the way of it.

Plus-sides:
- The story is surprising, relaxed, unexpected, and actually really good. It's so good that the actual gameplay gets in the way of it, BUT defeating bosses is satisfying.
- Cute Outfits, and roughly one trillion different craftable accessories to go with them. If there's one area where Factorio lacks, its in that there aren't anywhere near enough cute outfits.
- Noire's facial expressions. Don't ask me why, but I swear I have several hundred screenshots just of Noire pulling different faces. Yes, she is also my favourite character. I also think some of the trash talk in the item descriptions is a bit harsh about her, but I imagine it was meant in good fun.

84607288.review:
Although it's said to be a remake, but it seems like a complete different game.

Both the story and story telling are great and very enjoyable throughout the whole game.

The main game play itself is pretty easy dungeon crawling and finding ingredients to unlock more items/dungeons. Leveling up isn't as hard as I first thought but there are just TOO MANY things to unlock. Almost all items are behind a lock wall and we need to collect items from dungeons to unlock them for them to show up in the shop. Plus same name, same design item can have multiple unlockable copies for some characters, and that makes the game require us to unlock the same stuff over and over again with different drop/requirement just to use that same item on another character. In short, this game is super grindy even when the drop rate is very high for the ingredients, there's just too many things to unlock.

The Battle is a hybrid between turn based rpg + action button smasher + Japanese style Tactic (SLG). Loading battle scene whenever there's an encounter. But the game has given the players an option to "kill" the monster like a normal action rpg (without exp and drops) to get rid of the monster on screen and avoid certain encounters. Which is a great way to save some resources when you're low and camping for levels and doesn't want to hunt certain types of monsters.

But if you are only into the story, and not being a completionist trying to get every achievements unlocked... you can actually finish the game both normal and true ending ignoring most of the unlockables. And actually, you can get all steam achievements without unlocking everything in game too... So it's really up to you how to enjoy the game play.

The story alone is worth the full price and those who loves to grind and unlock should get all the DLCs.

84149933.review:
[i] ~nep nep nep~ [/i]
This was one of the first JRPGS I ever purchased, back in 2016. As a young teen, the speed at which one progressed through the game was alright, with thorough tutorials and many side quests to get lost in. However, as I have gotten older, I sense that the story progression is quite slow, especially in the beginning before you've gotten some extra characters (Compa, IF, Green Heart etc). If you are heavily into cheesy, anime stories, this slow progression might be right up your ally though!
As for the combat, it is a bit repetitive, and there are about 5 map layouts that are repeated throughout the game, with only a difference in what monsters pop up. However, I wouldn´t say I've ever been bored by the game. Graphics are great, typical for this studio, and the voice acting is superb as well. Cute conversations with loveable characters, [spoiler] especially if you buy the DLC with Plutia kappa [/spoiler] and if you grind hard enough you can buy them all swimsuits.
An important note to add is that losing progress is RIDICULOUSLY easy. I have had to start over twice and that is the only reason I have yet to complete the game, as I wouldn´t say the game has magnificent replayability.
Now as I have gotten older, the game has a special place in my heart. I will never be able to not recommend this game, because I, in some weird way, grew up with these characters. If you are looking for a game that will make you smile, laugh, and just genuinely have a good time with, despite the lackluster game mechanics, then this game is definitely for you!!

83207814.review:
Considering i've played at least ~100 hours total of the series on steam and own a few of the titles on my vita i could probably write out an essay detailing each aspect that i liked but i'll just cut to the chase.

If you're a normal person with lots of irl commitments and limited free time you might have trouble enjoying this game unironically. 

If you like basic comfy anime, have the time to waste on a JRPG and can look past superficial things like reused assets, you might be surprised by just how much enjoyment and content you can get from neptunia rebirth 1.

I'll note this first off, the neptunia series even with the rebirth games isn't known for it's stellar gameplay so you'll have to be able to attach yourself to the characters (which are fairly anime trope-y as the series goes along with rebirth 1 being the least severe with this at least; haha noire no friends! haha vert booba! etc.), appreciate the references to different games/consoles (is that mario???) and read the dialogue of the equally quirky NPCS in the overworld to push through the grind and enjoy yourself (you can use DLC weapons i guess but you wont have fun that way either, face noire like a man!).  

Game Mechanics wise, the only significant things you need to pay attention to are status effects and how much dmg is dealt to you overall positioning is braindead and you'll figure that out pretty quick. Movement within the small dungeons is basically walk around edges and hit them from behind so also pretty braindead there since they wont aggro you past a point. Also spam collect button/dont avoid enemies since you want to stock items up for plans. Don't go being lazy.

If you're worried about endgame content, at worst you can grind the colosseum (not that you'll really want to do that anyway since it's just about status effect abuse at that point). 

Personally rebirth 1 is my favourite in the series just because it has more of a focus on a smaller cast of characters, because seeing noire become more friendly with nep nep is the cutest shit ever and journeying to see the different nations and their leaders is a cool experience that isn't really replicated later in the series as their personalities get mellowed out.

10/10 I'll end it here Noire best girl, peace out.

81461314.review:
This is my first experience with Neptunia (which I got in the autumn sale) and I err... idk. Not a bad game by any means but:

- The characters are ok and pretty cute, but the plot seems to be pretty garbage (at least so far), ngl. The humour also falls flat imo (the gaming jokes/references in the dialogue feel forced to me, idk).
- No overworld like a standard JRPG should have, just dungeons.
- What's the point in a jump button if the jump is so miniscule/small? lmao
- I feel there should be more animated scenes in places where there aren't. Missed opportunity.
- The VN scenes feel like the most budget ones I've ever seen a "big" JRPG. Like seriously, even the DS Sonic games do a better job (despite there only being 1 JRPG on it). Like for real, the backgrounds of these scenes look like they belong in a 2D sidescroller or something. And the character animations don't have much to them here.

^ (edited in) Ok so granted, I actually like Persona and those games are sorta like this, but you gotta understand, at least those games have social sims and stuff to do inbetween, y'know.

- Resolution only goes up to 1366x768, and you have to deal with weird looking bars on the top and bottom if the game doesn't fit the screen in full. It's annoying, I gotta say. (full screen btw, I prefer it over windowed)


Yeah. There are things I find ok tho:

- Again, the characters.
- The OST. It's nothing incredible/mind blowing, and nowhere near the best I've heard in a JRPG, but it's alright.
- Said dungeons from above have fluid controls, so no worries there. And they're also better designed than, dare I say it... Tales of dungeons imo, for a random comparison.


Mid:

- Battle system. I DO like it; feels like Eternal Sonata's battle system (one of my favourite battle systems of all time) without the music mechanics and more simplified, but... That's the thing, it just doesn't feel as intense, just "ok". I will say though enemies definitely feel unbalanced at times. Like, I feel I'm currently at a decent level and some enemies would kick my ass at times ("some" meaning the other "some" enemies feel balanced, if that makes sense). Another thing I don't like about the battle system is, once you start a chain of normal attacks, you can't use an SP skill within that chain, and vice versa. Pretty annoying.

I honestly feel like the combat in this game could easily get repetitive tho, so eh.


So tl;dr:

- "Ok" and slightly cute characters (not the ones I'd wanna take home and hug all day, but hey).
- Forced humour/references (imo).
- Decent OST.
- Lazily done VN scenes, as well as them being pretty oversaturated.
- Really meh plot imo.
- Pretty annoying resolution options, but still managable.
- A jump button that serves no purpose.
- Decent dungeons.
- Fluid controls inside of said dungeons.
- An "ok" battle system; nothing mindblowing. Again, check Eternal Sonata if you want a better version of this one. Again, feels like it could get repetitive fast.
- Gameplay wise there's literally only dungeons you can sit through, which I gotta say, it could've been way more. Oh well.

Overall, with the time I had with this game I'd have to give it a 5.5/10 at best. 6 if I'm being generous. I'll keep the game for now, but the chances are I'm gonna be refunding this, ngl. At least I gave the series a shot, I guess.

In Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 you play as Neptune, an amnesiac protagonist with a penchant for pudding! Follow Nep as she makes new friends and saves Gamindustri from destruction! 

I definitely enjoyed Hyperdimension Neptunia and I look forward to playing the second one. While the grind in the game was a bit rough in the beginning, there are a lot of guides and tips you can utilize to speed things up a bit. [spoiler](Example: if you kill this guy, in this area, he gives you 100k exp compared to the 2k mob exp.)[/spoiler] 
The story line was pretty appealing and the characters were unique and felt like actual people rather than just a game sprite on a screen. I particularly enjoyed all the 4th wall breaks, references to other games, and jokes. Also noteworthy, the sheer amount of stuff to do, enemies, dungeons, and music tracks. 

I haven’t played a Hyperdimension game before, this was my first, but I think I can really get into this game series, and I recommend it for anyone that wants to give it a go.

79170476.review:
I can't say exactly why I love this series so much, but I do. I'd guess it's the characters because everything else besides the music is pretty average, average is fine, this game isn't meant to break any technical boundaries. The gameplay serves its purpose well enough. This game would most likely be better if they focused more on the slice of life aspect. Seriously, this series has so much potential. 
 It's grindy but I was way overleveled by the time I beat the final boss (My fault). If you have a hard time use exe moves and rush attacks, if that doesn't work then level a little. It has a weird difficulty spike with a lonely heart, use exes if possible and grind a little.      
I would definitely recommend a controller for this game, KB-M will work but it's not ideal at all, this game was made for vita and PS4 controls. A Xbox one, 360 or PS4 controls will work nicely. You may have problems with the resolution like not being able to put it to 1920x1080, this can be fixed in windows 10 by right clicking the game in steam library, properties, local files, browse local files, right click the exe file, right click, select properties, compatibility, Change high dpi settings, click the override high dpi setting box, make sure it says application, than click apply. This should fix the issue, if not there are plenty of guides on the topic. This seems to work with every other Neptunia game that has the same problem. If you use an xbox controller A and be can be reversed which is a real pain, you’ll just have to tinker with it a bit, Mapping A to A and B to B worked the last time I did it. Don’t ask me why. 

-Strengths 

Characters

Fun Light hearted and Comedic

Moe

Music

Premise

-Weaknesses

Vita graphics 

Overuse of assets

This game is great. Though being originally released in 2010 its humor, I feel still holds up. There is a lot to say about this game both bad and good, but mostly good elements in this review. This game is still great as it quickly became one of my top 20 games and would definitely recommend to anyone on the fence about it or is into comedy anime.

Surprisingly, bought this on a whim and ended up loving it.

The story is great, funny, and the characters are lovable. It's tongue-in-cheek non-stop and that's a good thing; the references are really good, especially if you have really good gaming knowledge both hardware and software wise.

Yes, they're in weird outfits when they transform, and yes there is some fan service, but it's deliberately done as homage/parody of what you expect from anime girls so I didn't mind it.

The game play is traditional JRPG encounter turn-based style so if you like that then you'll like this. Some might find it repetitive but it's fine really. Plus you can hold LB/L1 on controller to cut out the flashy moves e.g just instant damage which is useful for the more grindy parts.

Neptune is the best too!

Be warned; the DLC characters are spoilers for the other games so if you care about any twists in later games then I have warned you. That did bug me slightly.

Otherwise, welcome to the universe that is Hyperdimension Neptunia!

Nep-Nep, Neppie, Neptuna!!!!

As the first game in the series it makes an effort to introduce the characters, setting, lore etc. with the right pacing and order. It's like the developer has never ever played a PC game, EVER. Stupidly simple things like pressing space-bar to jump doesn't exist. The whole camera control is inverted. 74216808.review:
A solid, well priced JRPG with excellent combat and loads of content to keep you entertained for a long time.  You can usually find it on sale on Steam or some other website.  You only need the DLCs that cost .99 cents or less.

It's ironic that this game about personified video game consoles finds its biggest fanbase on the PC on Steam.  As of writing, Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;birth1 is in the 4th highest rated JRPG on Steam, right after the ports of older entries in the Persona, Final Fantasy, and Legend of Heroes franchises.  This is higher than this cutesy game produced on a shoe-string buget has any right to be.

It's a good game, and the turn based combat is beautiful, but all the other aspects (story, world design, crafting etc.) are merely passable at best.  

Overall, the game pales in comparison to the series it references, like Persona, Final Fantasy, Pokemon, and Zelda.  But fortunately for Idea Factory, those franchises aren't available on PC, leaving little competition in the PC JRPG market.  Sure there are occasionally ports, but these are few and far between and typically come out years after the original console release.

73662175.review:
tl;dr: 3 out of 5 / Very grindy / overly re-used assets / cute anime girls doing cute anime things.

I'm going to say yes, but cautiously. Hyperdimension Neptuinia Re;Birth1 is a remake of the original Hyperdimension Neptunia game, and IS the superior version by far. That being said, while there is a lot to enjoy in this game, it's very obvious corners were cut and game design was not the priority.

SUMMARY:

The game takes place in the fictional setting of Gamindustri, a land that parodies the current console wars, made up of Planeptune, Lastation, Leanbox, and Lowee. Each of these countries is led by a goddess who represents their country in combat. One of these goddesses is Neptune, our main character (and she won't let you forget that), who gets team attacked during one of these fights and is sent plummeting to the world below. When she wakes up, she has no memories of who she is or what she's done til now. So in order to regain her memories, Neptune sets off on a quest with her new friends Compa and IF.

GAMEPLAY:

There's not a lot to say here. Battles are done in a turn-based style, albeit a bit more interactive than just choosing an attack from a menu. Exploration feels a bit bare bones at best. You can walk, jump, slap enemies with your weapon to initiate combat with an advantage, and pick up items along the way. There is no hub area in this game, instead it uses the tried and true world map we've all come to know.

Now let's address the elephant in the room. Enemy variety is garbage. You'll be fighting the same enemies from level 1 to endgame, with maybe a palette swap here or there. The same can be said for the dungeons themselves. On more than one occasion you'll unlock a "new" dungeon to explore, only to find the map layout is exactly the same as an earlier dungeon just with different enemies in it. This may not have been as much of an issue if the game wasn't so grindy. You'll spend hours grinding on the same maps with the same enemies just to get your level to a point where you can beat that boss that just out of nowhere wiped the floor with you.

So far this review has been somewhat negative, but I do have some positives to say about it as well. The characters aren't the most complex or anything like that...but each of them can fit the title of "Best Girl" quite easily. The story is nothing we haven't seen before, but cute anime girls get to do cute anime things. And while the game itself reuses assets and requires a lot of grinding, I still had a good time hanging out with the characters.

RATING:

Overall, I'd give this game 3 stars out of 5. It's no masterpiece, but it's not trying to be one either. If you're a fan of RPG's I think you'll find some enjoyment to be had here. I don't think I'd recommend this at full price however, wait for a sale.

This game to me was a game where I can grind objectives, come up with ways to kill "Tough enemies." and then just do the side section of the game. I found myself in at lv 80 going into act 5. This game to me was in the same way that mining in Minecraft is for me the joy of finding diamonds after minging for a while. In this game, the diamonds (The joy) getting a stat upgrade. All the mining is filling up xdive (Used to do massive attacks.).

Other than the really good side potion of the game is the main plot is both interestingly written as well funny. The best way the writer does this is through the consistent use of the 4'th wall.  I played the game with English dub's. A problem with this is that some parts are not dubbed. This makes the feel of those sections feel sluggish at times but I highly recommend still reading it through as if some of the jokes fall flat the character pick up for the slack. The interactions that the character has between each other in the story is well done. Each character having parts for them to be showcased and each character having their "small" quirk about them.

The only problem I had with the game is its terrible mapping for the keyboard, the vague way it explains mechanics as well as no indication on where to find mats in-game (this is where having the wiki open is useful and recommended.)

Overall this game is really good I would recommend anybody interested at least to have a try and if it's on sale go for it I would say it's worth the money.

71677724.review:
[b]Anime JRPG with colored characters, and a nude mod from the community guides section should you want FBI knocking at your door... [/b]

Seriously though, I had lots of fun in this game. 
The story is there, albeit quite lighthearted. The gist of it is that there's a console war going on, but each of them is an anime girl called CPU. These CPUs each rule over a zone in the map and have their own Shares, power from people who believe in them. Many characters are available, therefore many possible party compositions. The game itself at least on the first playthrough is not too grindy, only gets grindy towards the final boss. What do you REALLY have to grind for are the achievements, if you want them. The player has one map with different locations, there's also crafting recipes for new locations, even new characters (in new game+) items and battle modifiers (make a zone more difficult or easier, change a zone's dropped items). I liked the game's difficulty, it wasn't too easy but not too difficult either (and as I said before you can change these aspects for some of the zones with crafting recipes). 
Now I do have the Colosseum + Characters DLC because I got them from a bundle, but they are not mandatory for your gaming experience. The Colosseum is a place for grind/ balancing out Shares (each CPU has Shares as you will find out later, don't wanna spoil too much) and the characters just make the game easier to play through (there are 3 characters, they don't really get explained/ introduced in the story in this game, they get introduced in Re;Birth 2 and Re;Birth 3 as base game characters, not DLC). As for the other DLCs I don't think they're necessary, many of them are cosmetics/ consumable items, some of them are characters/quests/zones but it's your call. 
The turn-based combat got repetitive pretty fast, but I didn't mind as I kept switching parties around on my first playthrough (it's cool that characters get experience even if they're not in your party). 

I enjoyed the art and the music, you can revisit those anytime you want in the Museum part of the game. Also, there's many pop culture references in this game which I didn't expect but were a welcomed surprise. I played the game voiced over in english, there's a japanese version too but I liked the english voices for the most part. 

I'll give this game a thumbs up, although it was a bit of a thorn in my side for the achievements (mainly because of the repetitive nature of the combat). The game has 2 endings, one normal ending and one "true" ending that needs a bit of work in the balancing Shares area.

71454849.review:
I bought this on an impulse from a steam sale, one of the better decisions I've made. The game is a typical JRPG including (but not limited to) anime waifus, risque pictures, fourth wall breaking, fan service, lewd jokes and pop culture references. Pleasantly it all fits together nicely (if a JRPG is your bag).

Pros
Graphics: Good artwork for the genre.
Sound: Passable for the genre.
Voice acting: Couldn't argue with it.
Plot: Suitably absurd. Good pacing, doesn't deviate too much away from the plot and the constant fourth wall breaking, references and fan service doesn't derail it.
Characters: Likeable, covers all the basic tropes you'd expect in a JRPG (although perhaps a bit too many of them).

Cons:
Slightly short plot, little re-playability other than to a completionist.
Very high hurdle for early bosses, requires patience to grind levels for at least the first 2 chapters.
Other than Japanese (duh) limited voice translation into other languages
Needs more Noire.

71061262.review:
Production value seems good, more voice overs than I was expecting. Most scenes have slow pacing because they pad it out with moe fluff and it feels like scenes drag on way too long (even the reference ones could get to the point quicker sometimes). Thankfully all that can be skipped/sped up. With that aside, I knew what I was getting into, as anyone interested in this game by now.

I remember vaguely playing the beginning when the original came out on PS3 and this remake's combat is less clunky and more intuitive (through research the battle system is revised to resemble the original 3rd entry which has a better flow). The combo system reminded me of a Tales game and had me feeling like this is what they would be like if they were turn based, so the combat felt interesting enough to want to see what it will feel like further into the game. (I'm mid Ch 2) Seems like it's made to get stale/grindy at parts and that there will be challenging battles in the future. 
Summed up: 3D arena, turn-based combat where attacks have ranges and go into combos. Has a magic and transformation system. 

I haven't gotten to do it yet but there is also some costume customization. Another fun thing I can relate to the Tales franchise which will make it an entertaining experience for those who like that feature (though it's more common in JRPGs these days I gather). 

Everything else overall seems pretty much standard JRPG fare for this day and age, considering it probably resembles systems (or combination of) from games I haven't gotten to over the years.

71050823.review:
6.7/10

+Combat is really fun with it's ARPG-like mechanics, although it's still turn-based. Making up your combos and using the EX skills was great!
-Grinding is pretty much a gameplay element here. The Remake system tries to make it less dull, but this wears out quickly. Which is a shame since this also made the combat loose it's fun after a while.
-The story is not great at all, and the only thing that kept me interested in the game was it's humor.  I also found it a bit difficult to stand the character's voices in either version of the dubbing. If you're not a fan of moe (like me) this might not be your type of game.

The game doesn't particularly stand out amongst the various RPGs I've played, but since this is the first entry in the series, I'm willing to give the rest of the games a chance (also I made the very dumb choice of buying them beforehand).

I really enjoyed this game. I played all 3 Re;Birth games back to back and I loved it.

It's partly a dungeon crawler with turn-based battles and partly a visual novel. It's a parody on gaming as it is and it knows it. The fourth wall is breached several times.
Personally I liked the humor and the characters. Neptunia and Noire are lovely, especially Noire. The battles weren't complicated and the pacing was relatively good. I say relatively, as the bosses had some different difficulty compared to the regular enemies. In that it's a bit of a grindy game.

If you like games that aren't all that serious, with a decent pacing, ok battles and don't have issue with half a game being a VN, then this certainly is something to play.

69560520.review:
A cute JRPG with over 60 hours of content plus post game content and a level cap of over 600 with dlc. The story feels a bit cliched and predictable and the characters are mostly happy go lucky all the time and don't seem to have a lot of depth to them. The customization is low early game because your money is better spent on healing items and accessories. And some of the dungeons reuse assets and reskin monsters and that isn't really a big deal with how many dungeons there are in the game, it's just something to point out. The combat is nice but I don't really see any benefit to using rush attacks whatsoever, power and break are better in every situation. There's a necessary grind within the first 10 hours of the game which is a bit fast. The game features a lot of references and is very self aware which is a good thing. There was a lot of plot exposition and Neptune chimes in like "our players don't want to read walls of text anymore," which was a funny moment. 

It breaks up the monotony with fourth wall breaks and references and doesn't take itself to seriously which is very welcome in this super serious genre. A solid 7 or 8 out of 10.

66377414.review:
In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#387 out of 612)... it's time for Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1.

If you've played on Idea Factory RPG, you've played every Idea Factory RPG. You know exactly what to expect: a technically functional Japanese-style roleplaying game that exists mostly to serve as a vehicle for otaku-pandering fanservice and comedy. The Hyperdimension Neptunia games are their flagship series, and therefore theoretically represent the best Idea Factory can do.

Their best isn't terribly impressive.

The thing about media that panders to otaku is that it's extremely alienating to people who fall outside of that subculture (which is fine: not everything needs to be for everyone) but it's also appealing to otaku who dislike being pandered to. I belong squarely in that latter category, I think. The Hyperdimension Neptunia games appear to be about nothing more than cute anime girls being cute, wearing revealing outfits, and making snarky jokes that more often than not are simple references to (now ancient) memes. It's all very superficial—there's no real depth here. If you're in the target demo and don't mind the pandering, or are simply looking for an easy laugh or two out of a game that won't demand much of your attention, Neptunia will deliver. If you're looking for something, anything more... look elsewhere.

64954910.review:
Si vienes a jugar a esta clase de juegos, más o menos sabes a lo que vas, travieso/a.
No obstante, a medida que iba jugando me iba gustando cada vez más cosas.
Para empezar es todo muy alegre, colorido y animado. Incluso en las mazmorras más avanzadas en las que te matan de un golpe si no vas preparado/a.
Me encanta el combate que es un poco dinámico pero sigue siendo por turnos, y los combos son gloria bendita visualmente hablando. Los efectos de los ataques pero su bien cuidada transición de golpes es muy [i] rewardering [/i] ( [i] recompensante [/i] por decirlo de alguna forma), aunque hagas poco daño.
La curva de dificultad es muy asequible pero si le añades los DLCs se hace increíblemente abrupta en las últimas mazmorras. Por decirlo de otra forma, el 95% del juego te lo haces fácil pero dichas mazmorras, que son opcionales, requieren de un grindeo enfermizo de niveles para que siquiera empieces a aguantar.
Aparte de eso, el juego tiene otras mecánicas muy interesantes, pero hasta que no te las presentan, de nada sirve que yo las alabe. Pero lo que sí que puedo decir es que si eres de esa parte de la población de chinofarmers, vas a encontrar goce en este juego al respecto.
Otra cosa por lo que muy probablemente hayas llegado a este juego es que no hay ningún personaje animado masculino. Todos los personajes jugables son femeninos y, evidentemente, están bastante sexualizados. Pero tampoco da mucho para contentar al de abajo. No sé. Cada uno con sus filias.
Ahora toca el turno de la historia. No te preocupes, no pienso destriparla. Sólo voy a decir que está llena de clichés y referencias a sagas míticas de videojuegos. Incluso los NPC no animados están basados en algún juego muy probablemente.

Conclusión: dudo que sea para todos los públicos, pero si te mola la estética anime y eres un chinofarmer, este juego te va a gustar bastante.

64833928.review:
This is literally Grinding: The Game. It's supposed to be around 30 hours long, and almost all of it is grinding the same maps over and over. I got pretty far but got sick of the grinding and gave up. Every few hours after you've grinded enough to get past the next boss, you get to access a couple minutes of overly precious, cutesy, bullshit cutscenes. The grinding might be tolerable if the actual combat were interesting, but it's far from it. You basically walk up to the nearest cluster of monsters and mash the attack button a couple times until you run out of action points. That's it. No tanking, no healing, no combos.

I could maybe understand playing this on the bus or something if you need to kill time and can't get too wrapped up in plot while you're doing it. Otherwise, stay far away. I have no clue why this game has good reviews, but I have a sneaking suspicion it has to do with internet weirdos who want to make the cutesy characters their waifus.

Just to let you all know this first nep game actually takes place in the Super Dimension instead of the Hyperdimension timeline so if your moving from this game to the second game it will feel a little inconsistant. The main story will take you from 20 to about 40 hours of to beat if you don't do side quests or side dungouns. If you want post game aka passed level 99 then it will take you around 80 to 200 hours to complete everything depending on your play style. Graphics are anime inspired so the game isn't aimed at trying to achive high graphical fidelity. Also just a warning if you haven't played any game from If or Compile Hearts. They have a tendency to reuse content over and over again so if you don't like that then well. If you see an enemy it will probably be in the other games across If/Comp Hearts catelog. 63130603.review: This game is good because of how bad it is. The voice acting, character designs, music, and most of the gameplay are good. However, this game isn't beginner friendly and is hard as hell. They're are way to many scenarios where you are forced to grind levels in order to not get destroyed by the enemies in the overworld. They can go from doing 0 damage to instantly killing your entire team. To put it simply, it's unbalanced and broken af. I don't even want to talk about the bosses in this game because they show no mercy in battle. The story is hot garbage and extremely long. I'm talking about 60 hours and I still have 2 more chapters to go to beat this game. Also, this game can't decide whether or not they want you to use a unit or not. Characters like Neptune and Vert are always crucial when things get tough but are either absent or get nerfed because the story said so. They're are only like 5 viable characters in this game and that's purely because everyone else's damage output is pathetic. My last complaint are the graphics and world design. What in the hell happened, this game has moments when it looks like low res ps2 graphics. The hit detection when getting near enemies makes me question my existence and the overworld is generic. 62292003.review:
I like this game but let's get the warning out of the way first... THIS GAME IS NOT FOR EVERYONE.

Why ? Because you need to really, and I mean REALLY love a certain number of things to make it work.

Farming. If you don't like farming for money and EXP, you'll get depressed at the massive amount of farm required to get everything. EXP/Credit grinding for the main story is not the worst if you follow a guide and ar not afraid to spend an hour or two at some key points to overcome some difficulty spikes, but if you're looking to 100%, grinding WILL be required in massive amounts.

Item farming. You need drops. A lot of them. Even more so if you want to unlock everything under the sun, as you can easily miss a plan for a dungeon, or unlock it too late... which means you won't get the modifiers for that dungeon (you can only get them for a limited time, usually before the end of the earliest chapter you can unlock it on, which is kind of a dumb limitation). 
Missing additional unlocks for a dungeon means missing ennemies, meaning missing drops... which sometimes means you'll miss unlocking other dungeons and items until you loop back through a new game +. Also if you miss something early in the chain, you might be missing 10+ non-story dungeons and all the drops from those, limiting your possibilities on that playthrough even more.

Random japanese humor, quips & "cancer" anime tropes. This game is so full of them it overflows from all sides. A bit of fanservice is also present, but I've seen a lot worse... 
It also requires a bit (but not too much) of console wars culture to fully enjoy since references abound. From Sega VS Nintendo to mid-2010.
In sum, if you dislike weeb and/or vidya culture, you're not gonna have a good time.

The game is REPETITIVE. Not only in farming but also in the general contents. The world map is a simple 2D plane where you select the locations you go to among those you unlocked. The dungeons are remapping of the exact same architecture... You've seen one cave? You've seen all of them. The plan might be a bit different with some paths/rooms available or locked when you get from one forest to the next, or you might find the exact same map, but you spawn at a different point... but it's still the same basic forest.
The number of terrains is pretty limited, like between 5~10 types...

Music is pretty redundant during gameplay. You'll get the same three dungeons music getting overused during the game, and they reset each time you have an encounted (which makes you hear the same first few seconds in loop between two fights when you farm... pretty aggravating).
I usually like video game music but this was aggravating enough to make me shut down music volume to favor my own music.

Sound design will be annoying for a lot of people. The characters will NOT stop talking whenever you jump in maps and at each of their turns/attacks/getting damaged.
THE NEPS NEVER END.
I like that but a lot of people won't.


Despite all that ! I like this game.
I like meming, the jokes despite their repetitive deliveries, the chaotic-stupid aligned main characted, the 4th wall being constantly broken, the farm, the ambiance and even the sounds.

Nep/10 would play the rest of the games... as soon as I'm done with all the farming on this one.

62256228.review:
This is a serious game for serious people. So this review will reflect that. This franchise had always been on my radar and after playing this game I can finally say... I don't get it.

This game took me 42 hours to reach the true ending. Honestly, it felt like 80. I can't lie, it was a slog to pull through this one. 
If you can't tell already and the big red thumbs down didn't tip you off, I don't like this game. Like at all. I think the gameplay is strangely unintuitive, the story is a hot mess, and the characters are less characters and more a loose collection of quirks and poor motivations. The combat system is pretty sick, but the game has quite a lot of grind so I got sick of that pretty fast, since you will probably be spending most of your in game time in a combat sequence. One thing that was unexpectedly something I disliked was the voice work, and I mean subs and dubs (Though the writing and written dialogue was fine). The music was good, but it's been a bit since I beat it and no tracks in particular stick out to me.
By far, however, my least favorite part of the game was the characters, or rather, how many of the characters were written, and the fact that I don't know who at least HALF OF MY PARTY EVEN IS! Like, they just show up during some battle and they stick around? But WHY!? The actual main characters were fine though. (If a bit bland.)
This sounds really bad when I say it, but of the 42 hours I played of this game, I'd say only about 8 or 9 were enjoyable for me. It had some peaks, but was overall just a big valley. Which feels wrong for me to say, because alot of this game are things to my tastes.
I like RPGs
I like Anime
I like Anime RPGs
But I really do not like this game, and after couple of hours into Rebirth 2 and how it is almost a carbon copy of this game's formula, I probably will not like the rest of the series either.

No hard feelings to any fans, this one just ain't for me.

[H1]Positive Points:[/h1]
[list][*]Interesting story, filled with comedies and 4th wall break. There's a lot of childish jokes, but I like the way it is.
[*]Wide range of characters personality.
[*]Interesting gridless combo-based turn-based-combat system with many customization option.
[*]Party system of 3 characters + 3 other characters for backup & coupling skill attack.
[*]Remake system, to make the dungeons feels a bit less repetitive, and tweak the gameplay.
[*]Cute graphic design & good soundtrack. Good voice acting, at least the Japanese ones, I don't really like the English VA.
[*]Vert's[/list]

[H1]Neutral Points:[/h1]
[list][*]Some items hunting requirements are very time consuming.
[*]True ending requirements are too easy, IMO.
[*]Many reused assets, but it's just how Idea Factory/Compile Heart works. At least there's a slight variations of them, [i]slight.[/i]
[*]Noire's[/list]

[H1]Negative Points:[/h1]
[list][*]Upscaled render image
[*]Lo-fi sound
[*]Blanc's[/list]

[h1]Contentment Score:[/h1]
And finally, for [i]"how much I like this game score"[/i], I'd give 5/5 – I love it!

The English voice acting is a bit of hit and miss, and is completely absent during the story dialogue.

59737968.review:
This is my first Neptunia game and I gotta say, it's really good. Graphically, the game is simple (it's a PS Vita port). The English dub seems to lack many dialogues (= lots of silent text reading). Japanese dub is fine.

The story is basic, but the game shines more in its many lovely characters and anime / gaming parodies and references. Dialogues are great and fun, and the fourth wall does not exist at all.

Gameplay is simple yet enjoyable. Short dungeons with a party of 3 members in front and 3 in back - swap at any moment. There's a shit-ton of cool skills to use as well as EXE skills (even more powerful skills) with great animations.

The remake system is a way to change some aspects of the game (new items, more dungeons, more enemies, …). Level cap is 99 unless you purchase DLCs.

In short : There's moe. There's the right amount of fanservice. There's pudding. There's good gameplay. There are great and witty dialogues.
And most important : there's Nep !

If you feel intrigued by the game, just buy it.
It's cheap and definitely worth it for any JRPGs fan.

59532707.review:
I'll go into a proper review later, but to start off I'm going to throw a weird little personal fact into this that is probably the best endorsement I can give.

I'm an old fat guy who bought this game to play while on walking on a treadmill, and probably 98% of my playtime is while doing so. Which means 148 hours, and approximately 425 miles later, this game is probably directly responsible for at least 25 pounds of real, permanent weight loss.

So yeah, this game is fun. 

But it is also weird, and I mean really weird. Nep. It plays like a PlayStation/PS2 era JRPG, but with all of the non-dungeon walking and talking (so, overworld map and towns) removed, and with all of the storyline dialogue done in visual novel style (with 100% voice acting in Japanese, or ~30% voice acted - and regularly at a cringeworthy level - if set to English). And the premise is so over the top, fourth-wall shattering, trope mocking while still following, and unapologetically weeby that even me, Mr. "100% every Gal*Gun game on Steam", almost permanently put the controller down a couple of times on my first playthrough. 

But the key word there is unapologetic. This game knows what it is and doesn't care. It's cheezy, goofy, illogical, and sickeningly hyper-cute, Nep, and yet somehow out of all of that comes a bizarre gem that is still rooted in the solid foundation of a well-made old school RPG, that only works because they committed so hard and consistently to the insanity. Nep-Nep. Though as a game it is highly repetitive and grindy, both on a small scale (dungeons essentially repeat with identical map segments used for multiple locations, monsters get reused so often they don't even bother palette swapping them a lot of the time) and on the grand scale (I think I did five complete playthroughs, the original and then four consecutive new game+, to find everything and defeat all of the top tier bonus dungeons). Also, the DLC is rather excessive, you don't need to have any of it, Nep, but bonus dungeons, as mentioned above, at least add a real level of extra challenge (or grind, if you don't want to dive into the fairly complex stat-sharing partner setup and equipment building and selection system needed to meet that challenge).

So yeah, it's fun, and I bought the sequel and couple other franchise games as well. Because Nep. And pudding!!! Oh, so much pudding.

.

.

.

.

.

Also, Compa best waifu. Had to be said.

56401230.review:
While bosses in the game come off as a little broken, the rest of the game is a pretty fun, typical RPG. the one thing that makes it stand out are the nature of the characters and the fact that the plot is based on references to the real world gaming industry and video games themselves (which, are geniusly woven into the text).

While there are moments of fanservice, it doesn't seem to overpower the girls lovable personalities. It also doesn't boil their personalities down to simple tropes. Something that usually tends to happen in Waifu War related content.

Yes, world building and plot transitions are mediocre at best, but what the game does very well is character development, well timed references, and a unique battle sequences, where characters have a set space to move around freely when engaging in combat. 

Overall, I'd say while HDN is not the most groundbreaking of it's time and may have a few balancing issues, it's still a good game with it's own unique charm.

55612721.review:
TLDR:  Two huge caveats; insane difficulty spike event at beginning of Chapter 2 (practically near the beginning of the game, two boss fights back to back) and a lot of grinding for levels and rare crafting components. If you can accept that then you'll cherish having this title in your game collection.

This game just oozes with personality, cuteness, and an insane amount of things to do. You can also choose between english voices or subtitled Japanese. Either way, the limited battle talk will grind your nerves to near suicide.

There's the basic storyline path with the full catalog of twists and turns that are obvious to everyone except the playable characters. Still fun to watch and participate in though as it does provide a well-rounded adventure.

Where it truly shines though is in the crafting of Plans. You have a limited amount of memory to create plans in, but I've yet to reach that cap. Plans do everything from introducing new items, weapons, clothing, and armor to the game as well as creating new dungeons to explore and ways to change the dungeons, such as changing what items drop, add or remove boss creatures (by turning the plan on or off), and even global game-wide plans that change difficulty from casual to normal to hardcore.

Gathering the components to make the plans though require a lot of dungeon exploring as you can only find certain items in certain dungeons, item rarity, and using previously crafted plans to change item drops and monster types in order to find the components you need, thus the grinding warning. If you're OCD and want to "get them all" this game will consume your life.

Playable characters are introduced regularly, but tend to drop in and out of your group due to the storyline, unless you buy DLC characters who are usable no matter what the storyline dictates. They're all cute, loveable in their own way, and come with unique abilites to flesh out and tailor your group to your own playstyle.

However, unless you do buy some of the overpowered DLC characters you won't be able to progress at the speed you may want, or you will hit a brick wall of difficulty and end up being one-shotted by everything. You WILL have to grind levels, requiring you to advance your team just as much as advance the storyline through sessions of grinding for levels. But if you're working on plans it makes the grind much more endurable.

Even with the caveats though I do highly recommend this game if you're into turn-based, story-rich, highly customizable game play. If you fit that description then this game, and its characters, will become a favorite of yours.
