55527813.review:
[h1]Cutesiest Game I've Ever Loathed[/h1]
[b]Summary:[/b]
A boring ensemble of console goddesses come together to save their world in this inane mess of grinding, lame jokes, and deeply unlikable character dialogue.

[b]Review:[/b]
So I had an itch for a JRPG and a tucked into a bygone bundle of games so far untouched; among them, Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1. I was willing to turn my brain down and enjoy what looked like a mediocre role-playing game centered around cute-to-scantily-clad girls on an adventure to save the world.

Problem was, I couldn't turn my brain down far enough.

This game has some of the most inane writing I've ever read. The dialogue, jokes, plot, and characters were so dull and clichéd I felt nothing but relief when the story sections were over and the game play resumed. As boring as the combat and exploration was, the story just made me mentally numb. Skipping parts helped, but then I was missing out of half of what makes the experience for a game like this; the story. 

The voice acting, where it exists, was either merely okay or really bad. The actresses sounded like they came from reddit or fiver, and then not from the best those places have to offer. I recognized a couple of them from various anime I'd seen over the years, but this was nothing impressive. On the bright side the voices are missing in most cases, and reading the bad writing manages to be a little less worse than hearing the bad writing badly acted. Actually, I'm pretty sure the biggest fault with the voice acting were the lines these women were paid to read.

The music is better in this version than in the original version of the game. The sound effects were also pretty good, but neither were anything memorable.

Similarly, the visual upgrade is very noticeable, and vastly better. The game itself looks bright and colorful, which is a refreshing change from most game's more gray, brown, and green pallets. The models and artwork were serviceable, and I've seen a lot worse, but it's pretty obvious this was a budget level affair across the board. The artists in this aspect were head and shoulders above the writers and composers.

Game play itself is pretty mediocre and [i]extremely grindy. [/i]I liked some of the aspects of the combat system, taking different positions on the field before selecting an action like attack or using items mixed things up a little from the norm. Further, different weapons resulted in different attack areas. An example right off is Neptune's sword; it may have a square or rectangular area of attack depending on the type of sword. It's an approach not often seen in games like this, along with an unusual take on the turn-based combat system that doesn't necessarily mean taking your turn and then politely waiting for the enemy to do the same. It isn't an active combat system, but it does a pretty neat impression of one.

Other game play mechanics felt needlessly convoluted, such as the Shares System and Lily Ranks. Plenty of guides out there, but it all feels lumped on, contrived, and ultimately unnecessary. These and a few other aspects of both how the world unfolds, and even the combat itself tend to detract more than add to the experience.

The crafting system is awful. You have to get Plans from dungeons and enemies to unlock more dungeons and enemies, and items, and events, etc. These can even be missed unless specific conditions are met prior to advancing the story beyond certain points, forcing more than one play to experience certain enemies or areas of this game. It wouldn't be so bad in other genres, or if this game had even been enjoyable enough to warrant multiple replays, but it is a grinding, repetitive, tedious experience. This is exacerbated by the need to grind for items and levels, and revisiting the same very shallow dungeons over and over again.

I am also not a fan of forced losing battles. Some bosses are meant to kill you. It can be thankfully quick, but it happened a lot, and is just an old lazy gimmick that needs to die from the genre.

This game was played with all settings maxed out using an Intel i7-8700k, 32gb DRAM, Samsung Evo SSD, 1080ti, running at 3440x1440. The aspect ratio is totally locked, making enlarging the game's resolution impossible. I tried running a mod to at least get it to match my monitor's vertical resolution, but wound up with a window that had the top and bottom of the screen cut off. It's weird and lazy, and not at all surprising given this game's overall lazy presentation.

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
    [*]The 'Skip' button
    [*]Bright and colorful
    [*]Different take on turn based battles
    [*]Controller friendly
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
    [*]Awful story
    [*]Annoying characters
    [*]Shallow presentation
    [*]Boring combat
    [*]Bland dialogue
    [*]Insufferable “jokes”
    [*]Heavy grinding required
    [*]Missable crafting unlocks force replay
[/list]

[b]Verdict: 03/10[/b]

I wanted a JRPG fix, and what I wound up with was a lot of the worst the genre has to offer.

54617033.review:
Well, this is a remake of the first game in the series, and it kind of shows -- I couldn't quite shake the feeling that it expects people to know a lot of the stuff.

Also, all those fillter characters like MAGES. -- I didn't like them in Re;Birth3, but they got better treatment there. In here, they are just random trash characters that pop out of nowhere.

Other than that, it's a Neptunia game. It doesn't quite have level of storytelling from Re;Birth3 or VII, but I liked how they did things. This is a different continuity from the one in the later games, but it works just fine as a starting point -- I've never seen Neptunia as "console war", so the idea that Neptune loses her memory, and having her turn into the Neptune that we know and ultimately ends the console war along the way worked just fine for me.

Oh, and since this is a starting point for a franchise, here we go: you've got some tame fan-service (this is "T" rated, after all), 4th wall breaking, asset-reusing dungeons, good but incomplete voice acting etc. This isn't a Final Fantasy big budget thing, but the unique world and characters work just fine for some people, and not for others.

54572148.review:
I was charmed by this game, unfortunately. 
The character designs are cute, and the writing is so whimsical it literally takes snack breaks whenever it wants, which is great fun, but the gameplay is so very tedious and grindy that I find it hard to believe that I own every gosh darn game in this series. 

I'd have enjoyed the game a whole lot more if the combat were less flashy and more straightforward. The break system sounds interesting in theory, but in practise it is a tedious patience-grating mess that really needs to be re-balanced or, preferably, removed altogether. Side quests are fetch as all heck, and the lifeless game design contrasts so sharply with the vibrant and quirky, sometimes charmingly annoying characters that I feel like these characters are trapped inside of a game that is not up to the standards that they themselves set. 

I beat this one, and I started the second, but I doubt I'll continue it even in the further off future, which is a shame, because the characters are great all throughout the series, and there are some real catchy tunes sprinkled throughout the OSTs too. 

With such bad gameplay, it's hard to recommend a playthrough, honestly not worth the trouble. watch a cutscene movie or the anime instead if you're really interested... OR! Play Fairy Fencer F instead - same studio, great music, same quality -if not better- characters, and while the gameplay overall is only marginally improved, the combat is LEAGUES better. Much more enjoyable.

54197964.review:
Hyperdimension Neptunia.... what can I say about it? I'm not fond of turn-based RPGs but this one was quite easy to get into, as well as having pretty fun dialogues. If you're into anime or memes in general you might enjoy this game.
[b]Prologue[/b]
The game is set in Gamindustry and a console war has begun, featuring Nintendo's console goddess counterpart White Heart, Microsoft's counterpart, Green Heart, Sony's counterpart Black Heart and as last, the protagonist; Sega's console counterpart, Purple Heart. During the last battle they had the first three godesses decided to team up and to defeat Purple Heart, which loses her memory, Neptune, as is, will meet alongside Compa and IF and will begin a journey to discover who she is and what's going on.
[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
[*]Funny dialogues (lots of 4th wall breaks there)
[*]Loveable characters
[*]Has many references to videogames (not as many as the original game for PS3) and anime in general
[*]On the long way you'll end up having lots of cute party members
[*]Compa
[/list]
[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
[*]Out of the 3 It's the most difficult one to finish as there are many roadblocks boss-wise
[*]Without DLC characters it feels like an endless grindfest
[*]The Dungeons are basically the same most of the time
[*]Compa is an useless party member unfortunately
[/list]

[b]DLC Characters [/b]
DLC characters, unless you don't want to spend endless hours in grinding, are highly suggested. The oracles are good for early game since they'll destroy basically anything but on the long run they will suffer as their equipment isn't as good as other party members in mid-late game, where basically everyone catches up. 53276717.review:
It's a fun game, but not for everyone, and there are some things to be aware of regarding the series. You'll probably either love it or hate it, and I'm certainly a fan.

First off, the Neptunia Re;birth series is a trilogy of remakes of games that first appeared on the PS3 quite a while back. To be specific:
Hyperdimension Neptunia -> Re;birth 1
Hyperdimension Neptunia Mk2 -> Re;birth 2
Hyperdimension Neptunia Victory -> Re;birth 3
Because the remakes use most of the same gameplay elements between the three titles, much of what I have to say about this game applies across the whole Re;birth trilogy. Things like the battle system are almost completely identical, and from what I understand, closely resemble the engine used in the original Victory. Many assets are reused between the three games, so don't expect to see a lot of new content past the first game you play. The series has a habit of recycling assets overall. If this bothers you, you may want to consider playing only one entry in the series. If you're in it for the story though, each story is discrete.

The battle system is a curious fusion of game systems I've encountered before. It has a movement and positioning system akin to certain N64 RPGs (every turn you can move freely within a circular area around where you started the turn in), an initiative and timing system straight out of Final Fantasy X, and normal attacks become controllable strings of combos that may vaguely remind you of Xenogears. Balance isn't exactly the game's best suit, but at least the battles are fairly engaging as long as you don't wind up hitting too high above your weight.

There are several customization options in the game -- most characters have alternate outfits which can be equipped (most of them being retextures, though) and a wide variety of head accessories, functional equipment can be designed to make new items available in the shops, the combo system used for standard attacks can be thouroughly customized per character, and there's a system that allows you to create passive ability-granting items that your characters can equip. Among other systems.

The main reason you might want to get into the series might be because of the characters and/or the comedy. It's not a game to be taken seriously, and wholeheartedly embraces anime and game tropes. To that end, it doesn't disappoint.

Overall, I reccomend buying one of the games on sale to see if you like it. You can start with either this game or MK2 -- note that this game is not canonical to the rest of the series. If you like what you have, and want to see more of the same but with different stories, get into the rest of the series.  Some new content is added with each new entry though a lot of it is simply recycled from older games. Each game in the series does make some minor improvements over the last one, though.

51927569.review:
Nice way to start with the Neptunia series.
The battle system is fine. Fairly standard turn-based fights.
Not too hard or complex, but some of the higher level (optional) fights still require some strategy.
The dungeons are pretty linear, and get reused often. Monsters are palette swaps in the later dungeons. This showcases the lower budget of this series, especially the earlier entries.

The real draw lies in the characters, and their interactions.
Story and dialogue segments are done in a visual novel style. The art and character design here is top notch. Characters look and act vibrant, and I love them. The voice actors are excellent, some of them being pretty high profile in Japan.
There are quite a few characters to choose for your party, each with their own, unique, skills. Balance wise, the Goddesses kind of overpower the rest, which is probably the biggest flaw in the gameplay department.
Every character _can_ be used in battle. However, for the DLC dungeons, you're basically bound to the goddesses.

If you like cute characters, turn based battles and silly humor, you might like this. Be aware that some amount of grinding is needed, though.
Would recommend.

51464490.review:
Have you ever heard of the story of chunky pasta sauce? Well, while that has nothing to do with Neptunia, it is relevant to me.

The general moral is that people don't know what they truly want until they try it and fall in love.  RPGs were never my forte, outside of Paper Mario: TTYD and the occasional Pokemon, so to dip into this semi-obscure, complete nonsense was certainly a shock to the system.

This game is not for everyone. Chapter 2 in particular is a very high difficulty spike that without copious grinding or certain very powerful DLC characters, would drive some people to go for a refund. I wouldn't blame anyone for that.

I continued out of a love for the writing. It has that charming character based humour that you don't see anymore. The comparison to TTYD isn't just for the overworld encounters (Though Crono Trigger and Earthbound did both first, but details. Going from [i]personal[/i] experience here.

I'm glad I did. The game honestly gets far better after Chapter 2. You start to get into the real meat of the mechanics, you meet more party members and the difficulty curve surprisingly mellows out.

This isn't even getting into the Remake system, which allows you to change dungeons, create items to buy and even modify game mechanics to do things such as increase EXP or Credits after battle, enemy strength and killing enemies on the overworld with a simple attack rather than fighting them. It offers a lot of depth for a game that does sorely needs it.

Speaking of lacking depth, do shell out for the various DLC packs. I certainly wouldn't recommend [i]all[/i] of them, as some of them should have been features from the start and were in later games (Looking at you, AV Club.) or are just not worth the moolah ([b]Good lord the Oracles.[/b]) but certainly the first 3 Additional Content Packs (Which raise the level cap to 999, along with adding some lovely end-game dungeons and gear to make your party nigh-on invincible. Additionally, I can personally recommend Plutia, Peashy and Uzume as solid and semi-balanced additions to any party.

If you're not into that (Not everyone is, even during a sale.), then there's some nice free DLC. Some item packs to help you out and Neptune's second best weapon along with a fantastic grinding spot. The other DLC as I said, probably not worth it. Giant and Mini Island seem ehhh and Lily Rank does [b]not[/b] matter nearly enough in this game to warrant the purchase. Survival mode seems like a fun gimmick the Shares quests again don't really matter [b]too[/b] much, but if you quickly want to get maxinum Shares in a single nation, I guess at that point it's your time or your money.

Man, I went way too long about nitpick-ey stuff. I guess at this point things such as the reused assets never really bothered me personally.

I guess I say [b]yes, buy this game if you want to enter the wild ride that is Neptunia.[/b] It's silly, self-aware fun with a decently unique combat system and a very lovable cast. Just a few [strike]hundred[/strike] caveats before you play it.

51328558.review:
An enjoyable and quite relaxing to play light RPG game that's easy to sink some time into. Even though I just complain about a few things in the review I had a pretty good time with the game all in all despite it having a number of very apparent flaws. Issues that will seemingly continue in the Re;Birth series from what I can tell, unfortunately.  I did two playthroughs, 100% achievements. Played in Japanese; no opinion on the English writing. 
Most notably there's the very lazy level design with reuse of not just assets used but the entire stage design of some areas. Reused assets are something I can stomach and recolored enemies in particular are no stranger to someone who's played many RPGs, but reusing entire areas with little to no rearrangement of the assets, and numerous times over again at that, is pretty bad. They couldn't even do so much as mirror some reused levels so that I could at least walk left rather than right. Something needed to be done to keep things at least a little fresh across such stages. 
While I like the idea behind the battle system with being able to move and choosing the positioning from where you attack the enemy, a lot of battles will be pretty static with enemies simply walking straight to their target if out of attack range or otherwise simply turning toward them. You'll wrap to the enemies side/back for bonus damage, they'll turn in your direction to attack, and repeat until dead. It's still more fun than had they went with a simple pick your target system, but it could maybe have been more interesting still if the AI had more moves up their sleeve. 
Although I realize the goddesses are a focal point of the series it would have been nice to see some more thought for characters like IF, and I guess Compa too, who are main characters but have absolutely no additional armors/costumes, a lack of unique moves, and to me seemed to become less and less viable the further you get into the game. Obviously characters can't be perfectly balanced but I would hope for them to still be at a useable level. It was disappointing to see even the late-game side-characters get more attention than IF. And Compa too, I guess.  
Final complaint is fairly minor. The turn-based system's display of the turn order is misleading because the different weight of the actions both you and the enemies can take will throw things out of whack, changing the turn order after actions taken. If you're not aware of which actions take more or less "time" the display loses a lot of it's value and can throw off your plans. Having some sort of indication that actions would affect the turn order could be have been nice. It is something you can adapt to with relative ease though.

51071105.review:
Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 merges a turned based RPG with a visual novel. The entire story is told by combining semi-animated 2D character art, occasional voice-overs, and text boxes. The main cast of characters are written in a lite-hearted, charming, and endearing manner with each having a few distinct personality traits. Due to this, the character interactions and story beats are frequently entertaining and a bit funny at times. Despite this, there really isn’t anything profoundly interesting about the story or characters, rather the focus is on portraying situations which are amusing and playful. This is greatly enhanced in the sections where voice-overs are included since the nuances in the voice performances help to get the humor across better.  The nonsensical storytelling and playful characters do a solid job of being pleasant for the entire visual novel section of the game, which composes roughly about ten hours of the total gameplay time.

The remaining fifteen hours of gameplay are made up of the turn-based RPG system. The complexity that this system offer is rather minimal during actual combat. Yet, there is still enough choice for it to be stimulating and require you to plan one or two moves ahead. In addition to this, there is a good amount of strategy that comes before you enter combat from having to selecting equipment, party layout, and special abilities.

One aspect of the game that stood out to me is the art. The small animation of each character in the visual novel portions really helps bring them to life. Plus, all of the character designs are delightful. The enemy design is also quite creative with floating 2D visual novel monsters, Tetris pieces, and a handful of other wacky game references.

Sadly, there are a fair bit of reused enemy assets in the main campaign, which definitely can seem lazy at times. I’m not entirely sure why the developers chose to do this, as there are plenty of side bosses that are completely unique. Additionally, there are two sections that definitely felt like they required a bit of grinding or completing unnecessary side quest in order to advance, which can be annoying for players who just want to progress through the main story.

Overall, I was quite surprised by how much I enjoyed almost all twenty-five hours of Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1. The characters are comical and lively while the combat system is simple yet stimulating enough to carry the game for twenty-five hours.

50967632.review:
[h1] It's time to pick a winner for MVP! [/h1]

A game developer trying to understand Minimum Viable Product could use [i]Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1[/i] as a case study.  Recycle the same maps with slight differences, create identical crafting cosmetics with different names for different characters, and throw in random treasure that you may not receive on a single playthrough, and you begin to have an idea of what would keep you playing this solid game with mismatched rewards for a very long time.

I can't say if there has been much quality of life improvement over the 2011 PS3 release that I have never played.  There is certainly still a klunk-a-junk control scheme present for crafting since you have to scroll through the entire Accessories list every time that you want to see what materials you need to create one.  This is so intolerable that, once I had established a way to make lots of money in the game, I made it a point to just buy one of everything in the Store of a Land so that I could craft as many Plans on one scroll through of the Accessories list in order to cut down on the time.  Really, a lot of the game devolves in just such a fashion as becoming a busy-list of repetitive tasks, like a 300+-hour word find, if such a thing existed. 

The best way to enjoy the DLC for this game is to start with all of it that unlocks at certain points in the playthrough.  Otherwise, you have to play through the game again, for example, on New Game Plus.  One of the new DLC from April 2019, "Shares Quests," allows you to avoid more playthroughs.  If you are a completionist, heaven help you:  Elegant Crown, an Accessory that can be used for Neptune's Plans for crafting other crowns, can only be obtained once per playthrough.

If you can tolerate not getting everything, the game is likely a lot more fun.  I stuck it out to learn the deeper gameplay of the upper reaches of the Colosseum.  Unfortunately, the power gear in the game, such as the six-piece Processor Units are a mixed experience when deciding between them.  Put on the Back of one set, seeing that it raises Defense, does not reflect consistently across the set, so that you might put on the Legs of the same set and have your Defense lowered back down.  Ultimately, I just picked sets for cosmetic aesthetic because of the complexity of the interaction between the pieces that mostly left characters somewhat similar stat-wise after switching gear.  The upside is that you get more out of Processor sets since you can generally change them per your whim rather than having to equip them out of necessity.

There are designer choices at which you will shake your head.  Chief among these is a Nepedia that arbitrarily only shows where monsters that you are hunting are found if you have the bits to make the monsters exist toggled On in your Plans.  While I humored this design at first, eventually it became too much of a time sink, and I found myself jumping to [b]Completed "Dungeon Loot / Monster Drop" list (Map included!) guide[/b] by Enfyny and trigger_segfault in the Community Guides here on Steam in order to do a Ctrl+F search rather than waste time toggling dozens of dungeons in a game that is about spending lots and lots of time trying to accomplish things.  There are more minor mysteries that I really can't say why they are the way they are, such as the head-scratching inclusion of partial Processor Sets like the Megapolis hat for Plutia that has no additional outfit pieces to complement it.

The battles are the solid meat for which you will want to play this game.  It's unfortunate that there are not many ways to boost your level by battling mid-game.  Perhaps the new DLC such as Giant Island and Mini Island help to cover this aspect before one is strong enough to take on the tougher DLC dungeons like Ario Plateau and Rebeat Resort.  The Giant and Mini Island dungeons, however, include only monsters without loot, so there really isn't much to keep one playing these dungeons specifically.

This is one of the reasons that I consider this game Minimum Viable Product:  the player is often left wanting more for one's time.  When it takes longer to listen to 27 level-up messages than it does to beat a Colosseum battle against Polytans when grinding, it feels like the designers didn’t really determine what the long-term fun factor for this grinding should feel like.  Regarding these messages, you can spam through them quickly by tapping, and still, 27 taps is an awful lot to do when you’re really wanting to build levels and not sit around waiting to hear how great it is that each character individually leveled up.

While it's awesome to see the developers still releasing new DLC for this game that came out over four years ago, there are some bugs that should have been handled already, such as some dialogue text messages in-game extending off the end of the screen, especially since there is now an AV Club DLC, released September 2018, that would allow the developers to review every single in-game dialogue without having to play through the entire game to know which ones need correcting and to check fixes.  Probably the worst of the DLC bugs is one for the Survival Mode that prevents one's score from showing for this new mode in the Colosseum as anything other than 0Win as recently as May 24, 2019 (Survival Mode released April 15, 2019).

Overall, I'm going to rate the experience of having played through the game and done everything as 7 out of 10 with 10 being a perfect game.  If I had had access to the Shares Quest and all DLC so that I would not have had to play through the game multiple times, I might have rated the game higher.  Slogging back through hours of dialogue again and again in order to access new DLC is not my idea of fun.  I enjoyed the variety of characters, and I wish that they had all been given equal treatment so that I would want to use them all more.  Some have tons of Accessories, for example, while others have just the clothes on their back.

The Minimum Viable Product vibe colored the entire experience for me from limited visual attacks for most characters (many just have 1 Exe and a handful of Skills) to only two types of Quests available at the Guilds (Hunt monsters and Find items dropped by those monsters).  I think that some of the DLC is the injection that has kept this game fun over the long haul for me, and what is sorely missing now that I've leveled everyone up and unlocked all Plans is that there is nothing to do end-game beyond a few tough Colosseum battles to keep me playing longer than the nearly 300 hours that I sunk into this title just to see what there was to see.  Oftentimes, I really didn't know whether it would be worth it to spend 60 million Credits on an ultimate Processor Set for a Goddess, and most times the answer was that I'd just sunk a lot of time into earning cosmetics that were not necessarily cooler than the ones to which I already had access.

50729440.review:
I played through Neptunia? What?
I no doubt got some eye rolls when people saw me playing this on Steam, but I won't lie, Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 is a pretty great game. The combat system constantly evolves as your level up and you're always learning new attacks to switch around into your character's combos. There's a slight learning curve to jump over, but once you figure it out, everything just clicks and it's really satisfying.
The storyline is actually not bad but oh man does the voice acting hurt my ears. after the first hour of "KAWAAAIIIII", "UUUUUUU", and many other high pitch Japanese sounds I dove head first into the options to turn voice acting off. Once I did that everything was much more bearable, although still pretty shallow considering all of the fan service panty/titty conversations and situations that arise throughout the story.
My biggest complaint with this game is the dungeon layout. There's probably 8 concrete dungeon designs. Once you've seen them all, that's it folks. In a game that has 30 or 40 dugeons to romp through, you'll see THE EXACT SAME LAYOUT get used over and over and over Class of Heroes style. It ruins any sense of exploration and shoulders a large margin of the fun onto the battle system.
Something I read a lot from other reviewers is the massive difficulty spikes that crop up. There are a few I guess but, they aren't bad. These few opportunities forced me to mess with the combo systems some more and ultimately made into a pro nep nep death machine.

So uh, to sum it up. Re;Birth1 is not a bad game. If you can get over the awful voices and don't mind some low-brow butt and boob shots with your day, there's a lot to like about Neptunia.

50691403.review:
I just wanna use this review to thank the developers for the entire series STILL getting updates and new DLC, 4 years after release.

The combat can be clunky, the level/money balancing is janky and super grindy, some of the DLC does feel like a blatant cash grab (like being able to have the party members follow you in the levels), most of it doesn't fit well to the story (not that the story is meant to be taken seriously anyway), but the fact it still gets developer attention to the degree it does, makes up for all of that, most games like this would have died off by now.

A for actual review, aside from the above, the graphics are still decent in 2019, it runs well in Steam Play (for us linux users), the story is entertaining and really doesn't try to take itself too seriously, it's easy to pickup and play for short or long periods of time, it's _almost_ fully voiced, i'd say maybe 10% of cutscenes don't have voice, and it's mostly just side story parts anyway, speaking of the animated Live2D cutscenes do give it a nice visual novel sorta feeling.
My advice though, don't limit yourself to JUST this game in the series, or just the newer games with the more modern combat systems, it's a far better collective experience with a degree of emotional investment into the characters from playing the several of the games, watching the series, etc, and this game is the starting point for the entire story.

50565691.review:
A fun, goofy anime RPG that is essentially a metaphor for video game history in the late 90's.  

Game play is pretty interesting and to me was a pretty novel approach to a turn based RPG.  The dialog is light hearted, self-satirical and constantly poking fun at itself and it's genre.  Visually the game is decently impressive for a PS Vita port, though it tends to have issues with nVidia graphic cards that require additional patching to fix.  

The need to complete the game multiple times on the same save file to progress to the best ending was a new mechanic to me, and seemed a bit strange, but after you beat the game once or twice, you're able to whip your way through the story pretty quickly, so it's not nearly as burdensome as it would sound.  I found it also mildly annoying that the game does a poor job keeping track or the items you have and don't have, making it very difficult to do an 'item hunt' type of game if you so chose to.

In the end, if you're looking for a game with an exclusively female cast that pokes fun at itself and the cliche's of the genre with a bubbly J-Pop soundtrack, maybe this is a game series you should consider.  I found the first installment enjoyable, maybe you will too.

50538535.review:
I have bought the whole Neptunia bundle, and now it's the first game from the series that I have completed so far.

Fully-voiced characters are something that I horrendously enjoy, as it gives a sense of liveness, the fact that you, as the observer, can take part in the story.
The soundtrack was literally a pleasure for my ears, fitting in almost every situation.
Cute characters, definitely a big plus. Nep-Nep definitely being my fav so far.
The Plan and Disc feature were hard for me to understand at first glance, but then I took it as a nice new tweak in this game genre.

There are some buts, though, those are the things that bugged me, not in a big matter, but still something to point it out.
First, the repetitiveness. Jesus man, honestly I never felt such a thing in any other game, as every dungeon "type" had the same map, but just with different enemies. Kind of a disappointment, which is actually something I wouldn't expect from a 95% recommended game.
The story. The idea is very promising, but the execution leaves a lot to be asked about. I assume the fanservice did the job, and I compensate this with the humor and 4th wall breaks.
The bosses design is.. Very low-effort. In most times you'll end up fighting copies of your allies, or just the same bosses all over, especially in later parts of the game. Not going to mention how you're supposed to spend 10-15mins in one fight with them regening HP, leaving you with nothing else than plan/XP grinding.
The additional content. Very humble and personal opinion there, I do not think it most of them are supposed to be paid for, I'd be more satisfied with them being unlockable instead.

Why on recommended? The bundle was on sale for a week, the moment I wanted to get it, the sale ended, but then it came back a few days later. It's amazing how often these guys are making discounts, and I salute them for this. They've put a lot of work into this game, and I appreciate it with my whole heart. It is worth giving it a shot if you enjoy cute girls over gameplay, or if you're just a casual anime gamer like me.

50514148.review:
I've played fairy fencer and it helped me realize that that is the kind of battle system that I'm fond of. Though halfway through that game, I was really disappointed that it was a complete train-wreck as I realized most of the functionality/ mechanics /upgrades were really unnecessary and pointless.

Then I found out that Hyperdimension Neptunia which has almost the exact same combat system as fairy fencer, and it was made from the same developer. I was immediately intrigued. However when I came to the store page, it screams fan service and looked really obnoxious to me. I was kinda reluctant so I stashed it into my wishlist.

Having it being heavily discounted all the time, I finally decide to purchase and completed it after some time so here are my thoughts.

[quote]
[i][b]Tldr (in my own opinion);[/b][/i]
[b]Pros:[/b]
+ Battle system
+ Visual

[b]Neutral:[/b]
~ Story
~ OST

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Genre? (not really my type)
[/quote]

The story... was okay-ish. Nothing particularly stands out nor is there much to fault it.

I started off with Jap voice but I really couldn't stand how all the characters are constantly yelling at almost every single dialogue, so I switched to English voice. It wasn't good either, most of the time the character expression was definitely lacking and awkward, but at least they're not constantly yelling all the time.

There are definitely fan services. Just play the game for for like 10mins and you'll see one.

The characters are... not really something to rate or judge as their development isn't really the point of this game. The characters are purposefully kept silly and typical for the slapstick to work. With the constant breaking of the fourth wall, I couldn't imagine it to work if the characters were to be taken seriously. That said, I'm still really not fond of the characters though. Let just say... this isn't my type of genre anyway.

OST side, as long as I don't feel any ear sore throughout the playthrough, I would say it is decent. So yeah, it's decent.

Battle system did not disappoint. Unlike fairy fencer, the functions and upgrades served its purpose and are useful. It's able to keep me intrigued throughout the playthrough too before it becomes boring. Plenty of characters available to play around with. There's not much intense strategy thinking needed for the boss battle. It's kinda like "just know what you're doing and you'll be fine".

All in all, I think it's worth the price when it's heavily discounted (well, it goes on sale pretty often so you should probably wait for one if it isn't having one now). But if you cannot stand or ignore fanservices and bland/annoying characters then I might suggest you to look elsewhere.

50414547.review:
Holy fuck, what am I doing with my life... 

I just beat the game with the True Ending, and I honestly don't even know what to say. On one hand, I adored the whole experience, and would definitely like to play more of the series. On the other, I just can't excuse the game's various flaws.

Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth is a hybrid between a semi-turnbased RPG and a visual novel. The story is full of anime/video game references, fourth-wall breaks, cutesy interactions and... yeah that's mostly it. Not to say that the there aren't any serious parts, though. It starts off with your typical "main character has amnesia" trope, then it slowly unravels that there is a malevolent force taking over the lands of GamIndustri, and you have to get to the bottom of where it is coming from. The dialogue which covers this part consists of only about 10% of the story. 

The other 90% is reserved for the aforementioned video game references, lewd jokes, cute talks about pudding, fourth-wall breaks, pretty much the writers fooling around. I love the fact that the game doesn't take itself seriously at all, and I personally adored the over-the-top nature of the dialogue. To add, most of the characters are fully voiced (JP dub), which shows a lot of effort dedicated to these shenanigans. 

However, it can get tiring after a while. Sometimes, the game has a serious problem with pacing, and the dialogues can get really drawn out. The main character breaking the 4th wall or the topic somehow transitioning to pudding was funny the first couple of times but then it gets thrown in your face way too much, almost to the point that you want to skip ahead. 

On the gameplay side, I can't help but praise the unique combat which I haven't seen in any other game before this one. You basically make a party of 3 characters (with the option to add an extra to each one as a backup later on) and you position them so that you can lock on to one or more enemies at once. You then choose which attack you want to use to make a combo. I personally had a lot of fun with the system, especially since there are extra dungeons where you can experiment with more enemies, and find more cool items. 

On the other hand, there is a lot of grinding involved. While the extra side quests, crafting (plan making) and characters kind of help against the monotony, you will be expected to kill the exact same enemies over and over. Once you level up, you will be expected to kill the same enemies, but this time higher-leveled. This leads me to one of the major gripes with the game - the lack of variety in the enemy design. Most of the mobs behave similarly, and even look the same throughout most of the dungeons. They don't even make an effort to change the colours, they just reuse the skins, and slap a new quirky name on them. In my opinion, this is beyond lazy, and only artificially lengthens the game.  

What is more, once you have leveled enough, the game becomes very easy. It never fully takes advantage of the position-based combat since all you really need is your characters properly leveled and to have the most OP items crafted (or remade, added in, whatever). For the bosses, just craft (remake the game and add) the EXE Boost, spam as many Rush attacks, then use the super-power (EXE Drive) of a character 2-3 times. Can't beat a boss? No tactics needed, just grind and then come back. 

Mind you, I still had a lot of fun with the game, and the combat system, along with the ReMake (crafting) parts made it really enjoyable. Just prepare a playlist or podcast, and make sure you are properly hydrated, because these parts can get hypnotising. 

In a nutshell, I enjoyed my time in the game, and I would definitely like to give the other titles in the series a shot. However, the various flaws make the game inaccessible to those who aren't into anime or video game references. On the other hand, if you like that sort of stuff, then switch your mind off and take in it all in. You will have a blast!

Nep is love. Nep is life.

50343112.review:
[h1]Hyperdimension Neptunia Re:Birth 1 Review[/h1]
Hyperdimension Neptunia Re:Birth 1 is a very underrated game. I played it start to finish and enjoyed it quite a bit. I previously played through Hyperdimension Neptunia Mk 2 on PS3 a few years ago and enjoyed that as well. This is a turn based JRPG with a great combat system. During battles you can chain together attacks to do massive damage. You can do attacks that do pure damage to enemies, attacks to break their guard or attacks to build up your EXE meter to do your character's ultimate attacks. Outside of combat, the character customization is great. You can change your weapons, armor, character outfits, accessories and can change their attacks they do during combos in battle. Battles are not randomly encountered you see enemies on the field run up to them and either swing at them to gain an advantage or the enemy gets the advantage if they bump into you first.  There's also weapons, items and other things you can buy from the stores at towns to upgrade your characters. A cool thing too is the crafting system in the game and the ability to make plans. Plans can create new items, weapons, armor for your characters, but also have other effects such as adding new enemies to areas, unlocking new areas to travel to and even strengthening and weakening enemies in areas. The story of the game is pretty good too.

This game's story is a massive parody of gaming and anime. So if you're someone who's into both of those things you will appreciate the many references and parodies to games and anime. However, if you're someone not into anime or games that much many of the parodies and references in this game may fly over your head. Throughout the game you'll fight enemies that resemble Ghosts from Pac Man, run into NPC's who look like Mario and Luigi, have characters make references to anime like Ghost in the Shell Stand Alone Complex and Steins Gate etc. Hyperdimension Neptunia Rebirth 1's story is not a story that takes itself seriously. It's very over the top and silly. Some people will like this and some will not. If you're looking for an extremely serious story this isn't the game. The characters have silly conversations frequently and the game breaks the fourth wall often. However, if you want some good laughs and can appreciate a story that cheers you up then this game's story is quite enjoyable. The characters are very likable and memorable. In terms of music and graphics the game is decent.

Neptunia Rebirth 1's graphics aren't going to really impress anyone. This is a budget JRPG and it definitely shows. Some dungeons have recycled assets and layouts and can look identical to each other. Furthermore, in terms of graphical fidelity it isn't that impressive and is unlikely to have heads turning. The attacks during combat are extremely cool and the areas do have a lot of creativity in their design however. Meanwhile, the soundtrack is pretty good. The game has some cool dungeon themes and the heavy metal boss themes are awesome. However, then there's a few dungeon themes or other songs in the game that are kind of meh and unmemorable. My biggest flaws with this game are some of the dungeons looking alike and also the anticlimactic final boss fight. The final boss fight was a bit of a let down, but fortunately the ending was really good. Overall, I suggest Hyperdimension Neptunia Rebirth 1 to JRPG fans. It is a great underrated JRPG if you're in the mood for a silly story that will make you laugh and that makes fun of the game industry and anime industry. If you are someone who's not into anime at all though and doesn't like that type of stuff you may not enjoy this game as much. Meanwhile, the combat system is pretty great and has a lot of tactics to it. The graphics and music could use improvement, but are more than serviceable. Overall, definitely give this game a play if you're a JRPG fan.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
Great combat system.
Story has pretty good writing and is funny. The game is a good parody of the gaming and anime industries and fans of both hobbies will appreciate the many references to games and anime. This game's cast of characters is very likable.
Really good boss themes and some great dungeon themes in this game's soundtrack.
Fun crafting system that is rewarding and worthwhile.
Gameplay is decently challenging and you will have to use a lot of different tactics to win fights.
Lots of character customization, outfits and ways to customize your characters for combat.
Despite not being a super amazing looking game graphically the area designs are creative and stand out. The character's attacks are also pretty awesome.

[h1]Cons[/h1]
Game is a lower budget JRPG and some corners are definitely cut. Dungeon designs are recycled and reused as are other assets. You'll go through a dungeon earlier in the game then get to a new one with the same layout and map design as a previous dungeon the only difference being tougher enemies/better items.
Anticlimactic final boss fight.
Might have to do some level grinding at certain parts of the game.
Graphically game is not that impressive.
Some of the dungeon themes and other songs on the soundtrack are kind of meh.

50257968.review: The game is extremely fun. It is an RPG, but it uses a unique gameplay style where you actually position your character in combat, allowing you to either avoid enemy damage or position yourself to hit multiple enemies. The game also uses a system that allows you to edit various parts of the game, such as adding dungeons to your map, weakening enemies or even adding more items to the shops using a limited resource. Small tip, do not be scared to use this resource, you get more than enough to get what you need and some of what you want, and it is well worth it to add dungeons. The game also has some very cute banter between the various characters, several times they will break the fourth wall, it might make you wonder if the fourth wall even exists at times. The only issue I personally have with the game is that unless you grind for cash to get better gear, you will hit difficulty spikes early on. 50204374.review:
I'm sure you found this game by going, "lol what is this anime garbage" and you are correct on both. It's both anime and garbage. But it's garbage you might enjoy. For an RPG, it's okay, I guess, but it can get old real fast. The story is... a story, I suppose, and the music is about as anime as you can get. 

I would equate Neptunia to a bag of sugar. it's alright for the first few minutes, but after a while, you *will* get sick of it. I don't mean just this game, I mean the entire series.

Neptunia is a game series that heavily relies on the player playing games solely for memes and anime references. The gameplay leaves a lot to be desired. The DLC is also bonkers, because there's so damn much of it, and it can get confusing what you have, what you don't have, and what each DLC does. For this reason, I really wish they'd just make a "Re;birth1 Complete Edition" instead of making it a mess to get everything. Now that I think about it, I'd rather they'd just make the DLC free updates. Most of it isn't even close to being worth the price for it. This is most notable with Hyperdevotion, which is a trashfire of a game already.

But why am I recommending it then? Because it goes on sale all the damn time, and if anyone wanted to get into Neptunia, then this is the game you play. I would recommend getting the Base game when it goes on sale (which is like... a few bucks, usually), and then play that. If you like it, congratulations, every game after this one does the exact same thing (and I mean THE EXACT SAME THING). 

Overall, I hate this series with a passion, but it's a love-hate relationship. 2% love, 98% hate. But if there's so many games, then I assume there's a reason for that. So buy/play this one, and think it over if you want to play the same game again while also paying for it, if you want to get the others.

50135101.review:
I'll start this review by saying that if I could have put a neutral recommendation I would have, but since the number of positive reviews are so high as to be a bit misleading I feel justified putting a negative review.

I finally bought the Neptunia games when they were recently in a Humble Bundle after constant Steam recommendations to look at them in the past. For the cost of less than £2 per game I thought it was probably worth giving them a shot and for that price they probably were. This said my problems with this game make for quite a list such that I can’t really recommend it.

To begin with the story is fine, but nothing really mind blowing (though I’m sure most of you aren’t exactly expecting Shakespeare). The whole idea of the “CPU war” is made pretty much irrelevant very early on by the main character (Neptune) losing her memory and most of the other CPU characters not actually being very interested in continuing it. This kind of kills one of the story’s main plot points and just makes it mostly about joining forces to beat the bad guy.

When it comes to the characters the biggest problem for me was that Neptune is just really annoying. There’s no real rhyme or reason to anything she says. A lot of her writing is just pointless filler with vain attempts at humour which I often found myself quickly skipping through for the other characters to get on with the story. I’ve seen other people say that you get used to it, but she has remained annoying to me for the whole game and into the other games in the series as well. I also found Compa’s voice quite irritable to the ear, which is a shame since the two characters are prominent throughout the whole game. The other characters all have their pros and cons and come down more to personal preference giving a decent variety with something to please most people, which is probably one of the bigger draws of the game.

In general I feel like the comedy element has been over sold by a lot of people. The comedy is on the level of any ordinary run of the mill anime. Very little actual wit or cleverness goes into the jokes, it’s more just the characters getting mad or flustered with each other or references to other games or anime series. A lot of the jokes are reused and repeated, which I personally found to become a bit of a drag and lack a bit of creativity further into the game.

When it comes to actual gameplay the game has some decent ideas that I feel could have been implemented much better, which left me a bit disappointed. The combat system is fairly interesting requiring a bit of thought as to what you’re doing with the freedom of movement making the turn-based combat feel not too sluggish. The combo skills set-up also gives you some choice over how you want utilise each of your characters. A problem for me is that as more combat mechanics are introduced they often have the effect of replacing older mechanics instead of adding to them. By the end of the game it feels like you’re mostly spamming “Rush” attacks to build up your meter to use the big EXE skills.

There are also several moves and abilities that feel entirely pointless. An example of this is the EXE couple skills. The idea is that they’re like the regular EXE skills, but you partner up two of the characters together to have a big combined attack, which sounds good in theory. The reality is that they require you to partner two specific characters, use up much more of your meter and simply don’t do enough to make it worth it. They also require both characters to be in the same form (Human or CPU), which makes the abilities awkward to use as well as limiting your choice of character partner set-up.

For a lot of the game the whole party and partner set-up is also constantly interrupted by characters joining and leaving the group, which makes the whole thing a pain in general until towards the end of the game where all the characters are available. This means you feel regularly forced to change your set-up and assist abilities every time this happens instead of doing so by choice. It also interrupts any attempt to increase the Lily rank between two characters (the higher the rank the stronger the characters are together) for most of the game.

Support characters and a lot of the support skills in general are also pretty redundant. This is mostly due to the fact that there are items in the game that simply do the job better and can be used by any character. Some of the stronger items do require unlocking to be able to be purchased, but can also be found in reasonable quantities as random drops and even then the more basic items are still fairly strong and easily attainable. Numerous abilities that buff a stat of a single character are simply dwarfed by items that can buff multiple stats to all characters in an area.

Sticking on the point of items, there are far too many different crafting materials. Each dungeon has its own set of enemies and each enemy has its own specific item drops. This results in there being over 300 different crafting materials, which makes getting the desired material for a specific crafting plan a huge pain. I ended up having to use a wiki page to figure out where I had to go for each specific item. Grouping together two or three of a similar type of enemy to drop the same items would have made this much less of a chore and much easier to memorise what enemy you needed to kill to farm which item.

The crafted gear is then also of questionable use. This is mainly due to the fact that most of the plans for gear require at least one item that drops from a boss, which are much stronger than any other enemy in the dungeon. By the time you’re strong enough to actually beat the boss the weapon you craft is often no longer desirable and quickly replaced or made redundant by gear easily purchased from the store or just found lying around.

Crafting outfits and accessory items is also antagonised by the fact that you can’t actually view the item until you’ve crafted it and then also purchased it, which means you’ll have to look up a guide if you want to try and find something that you actually like the look of without just doing it by trial and error. The even more annoying thing is that some of these items have bonus stats on whereas most of them don’t, which means out of the mostly cosmetic items a select few are just better. It would have been much better if none of these items gave stats and were just for looks.

Because of these things a lot of the bonus dungeons you can unlock are also somewhat irrelevant as if you aren’t looking to farm for new weapons and items there’s no real reason to use them as the story can be completed without them. The idea of course is that they’re optional, but it feels bad going out of your way to do some of the extra content to not really be rewarded very well for doing so.

There are a several other things I have issue with and could explain in more detail, but this review is already too long and I think you probably get the general point. There’s a lot of content in the game that could have really added to the experience, but just isn’t really very meaningful or could have easily been done better. I only really did most of it myself because I have quite a completionist mentality when it comes to playing games. Doing the extra content does at least alleviate some of the grind as it makes the game feel less monotonous with most of my game feeling fairly grind free even while getting the achievement to get each character to max level. I can see that people would say that the game can be quite grindy if they just stick to the main content though, which I suspect a lot of people will do.

As a JRPG, many games do it much better in terms of both story and gameplay and it really just comes down to how invested you are in the Neptunia universe and its characters. At a base level the game does enough to keep you interested, but its numerous faults make it not go much further than that.

49723854.review:
I've seen clips, memes and all kinds of weird stuff but finally I got to play thsi game and see what this whole Nep fuss is all about!

Neptunia is a special kind of JRPG - one that doens't impress you at first sight, but like... junk food it quickly grows on you. The game starts quite shallow, simplistic and repetitive. And while there are still some problems regarding these up until the end - my initial confusion changed to genuine entertainment. Suddenly magic happened and as more characters joined the fray, they grew on me, the jokes became funnier and the combat system more interesting.

The story of neptunia is inspired by teh console war where various companies and consoles are represented as cute anime girls fighting for supremacy, but do not go expecting something very deep and epic like most of JRPGS. The game never takes itself very seriously, instead you will get to see various inhabitants of "Gaminustry" (familliar plumbers, or suspicious soldiers hiding in cardboard boxes), lots of fourth wall breaking, references and silly nods to otehr games,  pervy jokes, [spoiler] light yuri [/spoiler] and girls talking about the power of friendship and pudding!
 All presented in visual novel format, meaning, lots of fully voiced dialog boxes (at least on Japanese settings - you have an english option as well but I haven't checked!) that sometimes might drag with all the extra fluff, accompanied by some quite colorful and nicely designed character portraits with some light animation effects. As with most visual novels you can also skip the long dialog cutscenes with a press of a button.
Music is appropriately cheerful and moody when it needs to, though doesn't have great variety - however,  the pieces are serviceable enough, catchy, with the intro song being the highlight.

Gameplay is reminiscent mostly of older JRPGS with a turned based battle system but sprinkled with some modern touches like being able to run around the battlefield and position your character in a way that can deal damage to more enemies but also avoid getting your entire group hurt by the enemy. As more characetrs join your party and as you level up more skills and tactics can be unlocked , though it takes a while until you can see the full potential of the system.
However the game doens't always escape from the more mundane basic tactics of spamming the attack buttons to empty the enemy's health bar and bosses dont' really offer much variety in terms of tactics . Neptunia follows one of the olders rules in the JRPG Book: Grinding and leveling up is all you need to progress.

Unfortunately this is one flaw that somewhat hampers the enjoynment in a few parts of the game, as it requires you to grind a bit and it becomes more frustrating in some questionable and sudden difficulty spikes (one being very early in the game). The dungeons also dont' offer too much variety, being mostly straightfowrad affairs with some having quite a few recycled assets.

There is an interesting crafting system (that admitetdly soemtimes can feel tiresome, as you search for the ingredients)  but it offers a nice variety of new materials, additional dungeons, extra enemies or changes to the gameplay system, some of which I consider essential to ease the more frustrating parts of the game.

The game also packs a nice viety of extras, like  a gallery where you can admire the beatiful and sometimes raunchy artwork and offers a NewGame+ for those who need more Nep in their life.

As for the technical aspects of the game, don't expect anything too special in terms of options, and as you can see the graphics are fairtly basic although still nice looking. I didn't encounter any problem with the game and my gamepad worked fine. Smooth 60fps!

All in all, Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 is a funny, lighthearted adventure, for those who want a more relaxed Jrpg, that doens't require a lot of thought or micromanagement, sometimes grindy and tedious, it might not be for everyone but for those who know what they are getting into for, it will be a fun romp and a nice introduction to the world of Neptunia.

I give this game a (＾ω＾) out of 10 Neps, Compa Desu!

49632869.review: I bought this on a whim since it was on humble bundle, and shortly after bought the whole series. 49619195.review:
Got this in a bundle for pretty cheap, went into it with fairly low expectations, but ended up enjoying it quite a lot. The game is split into 2 parts: The gameplay part starts you off in a hub-world, where you select a dungeon to go to, and explore an area and defeat monsters for items and EXP in turn-based battles. The story part is delivered in a visual novel kind of way, with character portraits talking to each other. Dialogue includes a lot of fourth wall breaking, as well as many references to all sorts of videogames and anime. For those who are into geek/otaku culture, extra value is to be had here.
Also got the DLC for this, which will be accounted for in the review.

Positives:
+Plays a lot like a more old-school JRPG, with a few modern touches added to it.
+Good pacing, letting you learn each new mechanic before introducing another.
+Setting up your own combos for the different types of auto-attacks.
+Combat flows quickly, with short animations on attacks, and the ability to skip spell/special attacks.
+Plans are a nice way to unlock new stuff (gameplay features, dungeons, gear, outfits) and encourage exploring all the areas and hunting for monsters. There are also a lot of plans to be found.
+Option for either English or Japanese voices. Just about every line of dialogue in the game is covered by voice acting, at least for the Japanese version. The voice acting is of pretty good quality, able to deliver the many utterly ridiculous and insane lines in a convincing manner.
+Nice character art that is slightly animated during dialogue scenes.
+Nice soundtrack. Catchy opening song.
+DLC that is priced fairly.
+Broccoli.

Negatives:
-Combat encounters are extremely simplistic. You've seen 1 boss, you've seen them all (tank'n'spank will do the job just fine). There aren't any real interesting mechanics introduced whatsoever.
-There were a few sharp difficulty spikes along the way that suddenly forced me to grind up some levels. Nothing too bad, but felt like a few of the areas/bosses could've done with a bit more careful balancing.
-The story is very basic and isn't anything you haven't seen before if you're familiar with JRPG tropes.
-Dialogue tends to drag on. Lot of fluff dialogue. (+Cutscenes can be skipped through quickly.)
-3D graphics are fairly underwhelming, even for 2014 standards. The character models look alright, but environments are basic and bland, with little interesting visuals. It gets the job done, though.

Could recommend, especially if you're into a more old-school JRPG experience. Overall, it's a good value package for its price.

49465236.review:
The game can be a bit grindey if you have no clue what you're doing, but the game does have it's charm.
Sometimes the story can drag a bit or try to be cryptic which just flops basically. But the charming story and characters more than makes up for it. 

Not a game i would pay 40 dollars to play as the game doesn't have much replay value, but if you got it in something like a humble bundle sale or steam sale then i'd more than recommend the game.

Be advised though setting up the game with the keyboard can be a task and a half as the game allows dual binding for game controls, which can be useful but can lead to frustrating and funny moments. But if you're a pad player then you should have no problem experiencing the game to the fullest right away.

Also for some reason my game was stuck in windowed mode but that's perhaps it's because my computer has below average graphics card.

49412540.review:
Well, saw the anime and been seeing the memes for a while now, I decided to try it. First few hours, especially the first hour, it was frustrating because key bindings were all over the place. After I fixed that, the game was fun. 

Voice acting (Japanese) and character art is so good. Only complain I have is how you need to do some side grinding to continue main story. I am used to games that level you enough just by playing the main campaign but the grind is not too bad. You'll need to search online for stuff that's not really explained like stats (VIT, MEN, TEC, etc..) but that's alright with me. I got this on sale but I'd say it's worth the $25 price tag.

Also, IF and Noire is so cute!!! Love their voice actresses too.

49406185.review:
I love this game and I bought it a few years back and personally after playing it for 150+ hours I would recommend this to anyone who loves anime JRPGs or silly RPGs in general. The combat is simplistic, the character designs and art are nice to look at, the dialogue and scenes are amusing and funny and the game is just overall enjoyable and fun to play even though it is repetitive.

However I do have one gripe and I hope it is temporary. 

Months ago Idea Factory released a remade version of this game for PS4 as this game was originally a PS VITA title. The remade PS4 version was dubbed "Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth 1 Plus". In this they basically just ported the VITA title to PS4 with all previous DLC. Which is nice and all but the other thing is it came with bonus characters and as of today it never got a western release. However some of the content such as the "Colosseum + Characters DLC" did get released for the PC version but we are still missing a few characters that the Plus version had.

5pb, Cave, and RED are all still missing from the game but I hope they will be included soon. Anyways that was my gripe but it isn't game breaking so I still recommend this game but I do hope that the content does get added to the Steam version eventually seeing how we already got a bit of the DLC. I wouldn't even mind paying for it either so please add it. But yes HDN RB1 is a great fun little game and even better if you catch it on sale.

49278745.review:
Pros
-A good opening before the title screen
-A great beginning for the story
-Story builds up nicely, not too rush
-Great background music that makes you feel like you're in an adventure
-The game's tutorials/guides are very useful, if you read them :P
-A lot of mini games in the colosseum battles. Challenging, it's not like your usual doggo enemies
-Game gets more interesting when more character joins in
-Character design is beautiful
-The museum is the place to relax and see the album
-Cute girls, yes
-More cute girls, yes
-Doesn't require a high end pc

Cons
-Game sometimes crashes before you even save the game 
-The sound of the music is kinda buggy during battles 
-The battle gameplay can be improved
-Plans are stacked, cant be sorted 
-Grinding levels like hell
-Earning credits very slowly for the 100mil achievement
-[b]Vert doesn't have a sister [/b]

Overall a good game for fellow weebs, but the more dlc you buy the more time you'll spend time grinding levels for your character. It's fun tho, git it.

48858900.review:
Beware: This JRPG contains super cute girls and it's guaranteed that you will grow fond of all the girls very soon and won't be able to separate yourself from them. They will make you laugh, sigh and fall in love. Are you ready for a journey with them?

Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 is the first game of the Hyperdimension Neptunia Series, however, they all are stand-alones. The only thing you should pay attention to is that it's recommended to play Re;Birth1 before starting the third game, since Re;Birth3 is a spin-off of the first game.

As Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 always was extremely popular, I just had to play it as well at some point. I have to say, I didn’t expect a lot since this game looks like your typical fan-service based anime game. Oh, little did I know. Never did I think I would enjoy such a game as much as I did.

Gameindustri is a world protected by four CPUs. CPUs are goddesses who protect their own planets, therefore there are a total of four plants: Planeptune, Lastation, Leanbox, and Lowee. The atmosphere is very tense, as all CPUs are fighting for world domination. Suddenly, random monsters get released by Arfoire. Neptune, who is one of the four CPUs, gets defeated and loses all of her memories. She wakes up in the lower realm and meets IF and Compa without knowing she is actually Purple Heart, the CPU of Planeptune. Gameindustri is in great danger. Will Neptune be able to regain her memories and more importantly, will she and her friends be able to save the world?

The story is very simple and light-hearted. It’s nothing new, as many JRPG games have the same storyline. Basically, you just have a villain who wants to destroy the world and a hero who will try to save mankind, this game is no exception. The story is definitely not the focus of this game and that won't keep you playing the game, but the humor and the lovable characters make up for it.

The characters are very adorable and silly to a point it was funny. Every character is unique and completely different, though all of them are very cute. Neptune doesn’t seem like the smartest girl and is basically an air-head. You really end up shaking your head while laughing and reading her comments. On the side note, you definitely won’t be able to not love her. She never gives up and always tries her best. I would say she can be serious when it is required even if she acts very immature. Noire, on the other hand, is your typical tsundere. She is too shy to admit her real feelings, yet you can tell she really cares about her friends. I really enjoyed the interactions between the characters, for example, everyone teasing Blanc or Noire for… Specific reasons. Vert is a very lovable character as well, she is a very huge nerd and loves to game in her free time. But of course, it’s a secret! She loves anything that’s cute and small, and she especially loves to hug people, a lot!

Some might say that the characters are a bit overly cute and I can definitely agree. They indeed act very cutely and some may be put off by it. However, it never bothered me while playing. I mean what kind of game is realistic? Definitely not a JRPG.

First of all, the visuals and CGs are gorgeous. The characters do have plenty of different facial expressions and they’re very lively. You can literally imagine how the girls would look like if they were 100% animated. Also, you can notice the art is really detailed. The dungeons are a bit empty though, they’re very straight forward and only contain glimpses of what could be there. For example, if there is snow, it’s just white. Not detailed at all, just white. The focus on graphics definitely lies in the artwork and CGs, but I wished they would have focused more on the dungeons because it’s also the only place where you can walk around more or less freely.

Also, I have to mention some enemies may seem very weird to you, as they are not all monsters per se. Instead, there are very different visuals for each monster, also including posters for example… It felt very weird fighting against an enemy when they were designed as a thing literally, but it was definitely not a deal breaker.

This game has English and Japanese Voice Over. I played the game with English-Voice-Acting, so I’ll be able to only critique the English one. I really enjoyed listening to the girls’ talking as the voices really fit for each character, I would have imagined them exactly with the same voice given their personality. The Voice Acting really is top notch. Although English-Voice-Over often sounds a bit off in original Japanese games, it didn’t feel this way for Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 at all. They all sound very natural and of course cute and lovable!

So in the end, would I recommend Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1? My answer would be: definitely! While this game does not contain an outstanding story, nor gameplay, I couldn’t put my controller down. Just the dialogue of the main characters and their friendship alone were enough to keep me going. I don’t think Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 is a game anyone would enjoy, if you are into a story-driven game or enjoy good a combat style, you should look elsewhere. But if you enjoy character development, a fluffy story and don’t mind a typical JRPG you will absolutely adore this game. I can say I’m glad my journey with Neptunia and her friends didn’t end here since there are more games of this series which I will definitely play in the future.

If you enjoy this game, you'll definitely enjoy the ones that come after as well, so definitely give it a try.

48178437.review: so this is the first in a series of remakes of hyperdimension neptunia, a jrpg series that originated on the playstation 3. if you have played this game (trying not to spoil anything here) you know this series is basically a satire of the long history of video games. each of the four nations are named after a console, for example lastation is named after the playstation and leanbox is obviously named after the xbox. and the wars waged between the nations is representative of the video game wars, such as ps3 vs the 360. and with plenty of comedic relief thrown in, it can be hard to take this game seriously, but that's part of the enjoyment. on a side note, there is an anime series based on the games, but it's not necessary to watch it for the purposes of this game, but i thoroughly enjoyed it. you can find it on crunchyroll and i think it was on netflix recently but i don't know if its still there. but back to the game: the story and combat systems were completely overhauled for this remake, and that's a good thing, as i did not particularly enjoy the way the original worked. in short, play this game, and the two sequels, which are called sister's generation and v generation.
